Lange Passwörter nicht erlaubt
Es ist nicht möglich, lange Passworte zu setzen. Die Länge ist auf \<XXX\> Zeichen beschränkt.

Ein Benutzer wird daher bei der Wahl eines sicheren Passwortes eingeschränkt und die Kompromittierung von Konten vereinfacht.

UAC für den Benutzer "Administrator" nicht aktiv
Der Administratorgenehmigungsmodus ist für das Standard-Administratorenkonto nicht aktiviert.

Dadurch werden alle Applikationen dieses Kontos mit vollen Administrationsrechten gestartet. Weiter wird so nicht verhindert, dass mithilfe von diesem Konto über das Netzwerk auf dem Gerät Befehle ausgeführt werden.

X-XSS-Protection header not set
The "X-XSS-Protection" header is not set.

X-XSS-Protection determines the configuration for the cross-site scripting filter built into most browsers and helps therefore to prevent XSS-attacks.

[ASVS 14.4.4] [Web] X-Content-Type-Options
The "X-Content-Type-Options" HTTP header is not set. This header asks web browsers to trust the MIME type declared by the web server.

Without "X-Content-Type-Options", web browsers could try to guess the MIME type by parsing the response (MIME sniffing). This results in a security risk since an adversary could, for example, embed JavaScript code in a response with a MIME type that in fact prevents execution. With MIME sniffing, a web browser could overrule the server and execute the code, rendering the web application vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS).

SSH Cipher Block Chaining (CBC)

The SSH server supports ciphers using Cipher Block Chaining (CBC) mode. Several attacks are known for this kind of encryption mode, which allow partial decryption of the transmitted data.

NTP Server

An NTP server is active and returning the precise system time. This may help an attacker to conduct an attack on time based authentication protocols.

Network Time Protocol Denial of Service
The version of the NTP (Network Time Protocol) server running on the remote host has a denial-of-service vulnerability.

This gives the potential to be used in NTP amplification attacks. An unauthenticated, remote attacker could potentially exploit this to cause a reflected denial-of-service condition.

Signing Disabled on SMB Server

Signing is disabled on the remote Server Message Block (SMB) server. This may allow man-in-the-middle attacks against the SMB server.

SSH Weak MAC Algorithms

The SSH server is configured to allow weak MD5 and/or 96-bit MAC algorithms.

This eases attacks on the integrity of the connection.

SSH Weak Algorithms

The SSH server is configured to utilize the Arcfour stream cipher. This cipher is considered to have issues with weak keys

For more information, see:

* RFC 4253

POODLE
The server supports the protocol SSLv3 in combination with CBC ciphers.

CBC ciphers in SSLv3 are susceptible to the "Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy Encyption" (POODLE) vulnerability. The vulnerability allows an attacker in a man-in-the-middle position to decrypt the transmitted message.

Additionally an attacker can manipulate its victim to negotiate a connection over SSLv3 even though it would support more secure protocols. This reduces the confidentiality guarantees.

For further information see:

* https://www.openssl.org/\~bodo/ssl-poodle.pdf

TLS CBC Modes
The server supports SSL/TLS ciphers that are used in the "Cipher Block Chaining" (CBC) mode.

For this mode, multiple attacks on the client connection are known that may under certain circumstances allow the decryption of parts of the data.

The attacks are BEAST, POODLE and similar attacks.

FTP Clear Text Authentication
Over FTP, username and password as well as files are transmitted in clear text (not encrypted).

For an attacker it is therefore easily possible to eavesdrop on the communication between the client and the server.

HTTP Strict Transport Security Header Missing
The server communicates using HTTPS and the "HTTP Strict Transport Security" (HSTS) header is not set.

Thus, it is possible that data is transmitted over an unencrypted HTTP connection. This may provoke man-in-the-middle attacks.

For more details visit:

* https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security

SMBv1
The server supports the Server Message Block protocol version 1 (SMBv1).

Microsoft recommends that users discontinue the use of SMBv1.

This version lacks security features of later versions, such as encryption and prevention mechanisms for specific security downgrade attacks, which may allow an attacker to eavesdrop on the communication and perform man-in-the-middle attacks.

SMB NULL Session

The remote host is running Microsoft Windows. It is possible to log into it using a NULL session (i.e. with no login or password).

Depending on the configuration, it may be possible for an unauthenticated, remote attacker to leverage this issue to get information about the remote host.

Certificate Signed with Weak Hashing Algorithm

The remote service uses an SSL certificate that has been signed using a cryptographically weak hashing algorithm. This signature algorithm is known to be vulnerable to collision attacks. A determined attacker may be able to leverage this weakness to generate another certificate with the same digital signature, which could allow him to masquerade as the affected service.

SSL/TLS RC4
The TLS/SSL server supports the stream cipher RC4.

The encryption algorithm RC4 has severe cryptographic weaknesses.

An attacker could use these weaknesses to recover the plaintext of the encrypted messages.

TLS Expired
The TLS certificate has expired.

An expired certificate is invalid and will therefore be rejected by all client software.

In case of the client software being a browser a user can either ignore the error message, which will reinforce the idea that security warnings can be ignored, or not interact with the service at all.

NTP monlist Command

The NTP service of the host supports the monlist command. This can be used to retrieve a list of IP addresses that recently accessed the service. Furthermore, the output could be abused for denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.

Legacy Transport Encryption Protocol
The server supports a legacy version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. This version uses encryption schemes that do not provide the same security guarantees as the current standard.

An attacker with sufficient resources can, under certain conditions, attack the legacy encryption and therefore read the transmitted messages.

Further information:

* https://blog.pcisecuritystandards.org/are-you-ready-for-30-june-2018-sayin-goodbye-to-ssl-early-tls
* https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2018/10/15/removing-old-versions-of-tls/
* https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2018/10/15/modernizing-tls-edge-ie11/
* https://security.googleblog.com/2018/10/modernizing-transport-security.html


Note: All major browser vendors have announced that they will no longer support TLS 1.0 and 1.1 from 2020.

SSL Version 2
The server supports the protocol SSLv2.

SSLv2 is a legacy protocol with multiple severe cryptographic weaknesses which affect the integrity and confidentiality of the connection negatively. For example an attacker may decrypt the transmitted data or perform man-in-the-middle attacks.

SMB Guest Access

The SMB service allows anonymous logins with the user "Guest".

SMB Version 1 Exploitable
The system's Microsoft Server Message Block 1.0 (SMBv1) service is affected by multiple vulnerabilities.

An unauthenticated, remote attacker can exploit these vulnerabilities to execute arbitrary code on the system.

Exploits for these vulnerabilities are available on the internet and were already used by malware (e.g. WannaCry).

OpenSSH MaxAuth Tries Bypass

The installed version of OpenSSH does not properly check the list of keyboard-interactive authentication methods for duplicates. A remote attacker could use this flaw to bypass the MaxAuthTries limit, making it easier to perform password guessing attacks.

Self-Signed Certificate
The SSL certificate of the service is self-signed.

The authenticity of the certificate and therefore also the service cannot be verified.

This makes the service vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.

TLS Cipher Key Length < 128 Bit
The server accepts SSL/TLS connections with weak ciphers. Weak ciphers use keys shorter than 128 bits.

An attacker could use this fact to decrypt and read captured data.

Finger Service Remote Information Disclosure

The "finger" service is running on the system. This service allows finding out which users are currently logged on to the system and information about the users can be queried. This can be very valuable information for an attacker to find out how and when a user uses the system.

Unknown Certificate Authority

The SSL certificate of the website is signed by an unknown Certification Authority. This makes it impossible to verify the authenticity of the server and makes it vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.

SSL/TLS Initialization Vector Information Disclosure

The TLS/SSL implementation of the server offers ciphers that may allow an attacker to read parts of the encrypted communication (BEAST attack).

The server cannot be directly attacked through this weakness, but vulnerable clients may potentially be spied upon.

Badlock

There exists a vulnerability in the Security Account Manager (SAM) and the Local Security Authority (Domain Policy) (LSAD) protocols.

The attacker can control the communication between client and the server running a SAM database by using a man-in-the-middle attack .

The attacker can imitate an authenticated user and access confidential data.

System Name and Joined Domain Name Disclosure
The remote system discloses its name and the name of the domain it belongs to during a NTLMSSP authentication.

This may allow an attacker to gain valuable information about the affected system and the network.

Echo Service
The systems runs the "echo" service. This service echoes any data which is sent to it.

This service can be utilized by an attacker to set up denial of service (DoS) attacks against this host.

SMB Version 1 Vulnerabilities
The system supports Microsoft's Server Message Block Version 1.0 (SMBv1), which is affected by a number of vulnerabilities.

The server is affected by a number of information disclosure, denial of service and remote code execution vulnerabilities. In the worst case an attacker is able to take over the host.

Windows Server Remote Code Execution
The Windows "Server" service running on the devices handles RPC requests incorrectly.

An unauthenticated remote attacker is able to execute code on the device with "System" privileges.

Remote Desktop Vulnerabilities
The Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) implementation is vulnerable.

An attacker is able to remotely execute code on the system.

FTP Anonymous Login
The FTP server allows logins with the user "anonymous" and/or "Guest" without password.

An attacker could access any files accessible by the corresponding user.

Default Web Page
The web server uses the default welcome page which is provided by the installation utility.

The default page reveals information about the web server technology and version in use. An attacker could use this information to search for vulnerabilities which are specific to that version.

RDP not FIPS-140 Compliant
The Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) service is using weak cryptography.

By using weak cryptography an attacker could eavesdrop on the communication between client and server or manipulate exchanged messages.

TFTP Server
A TFTP (Trivial File Transfer Protocol) service is running on the device.

The TFTP protocol does not include any security mechanisms to protect the stored data. Which allows an attacker to access the corresponding files.

Short Public Key
The public key of the used TLS/SSL certificate or a certificate in the certificate chain is shorter than 2048 bits.

An attacker might be able to derive the private key of such weak keys and is therefore able to decrypt past (unless FPS mode was used) and future TLS/SSL secured connections if he is able to intercept the encrypted traffic.

Man-in-the-Middle RDP Vulnerability
The current Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) service is vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.

An attacker could decrypt the communication between the client and server to gain access to sensitive information such as user names an passwords.

Future Certificate Expiry
The SSL/TLS certificate will expire in the near future.

An expired certificate is not trust-worthy and clients will not be able to connect to the service.

SMTP Server on Non-Standard Port
An SMTP server runs on the system on an unusual port.

This server cannot be used as an incoming mail server as sending mail servers expect a listening port on the default port 25.

As an outgoing mail server, this could be a rogue service which is used for data exfiltration or the distribution of SPAM.

IPSEC IKE Phase 1 Aggressive Mode
Aggressive mode is active in phase one of the Internet Key Exchange (IKE) protocol. The hash value of the pre-shared key (PSK) is transmitted in plaintext in this mode.

An attacker who is able to access this value can crack it offline with a tool like psk-crack.

Therefore, the security guarantees of this exchange is strongly based on the complexity of the configured PSK.

SMB Memory Corruption Vulnerability
The Microsoft Windows SMB service is vulnerable to a memory corruption.

An attacker could exploit this to execute arbitrary code or perform a denial-of-service attack.

Anti-Clickjacking X-Frame-Options
The anti-clickjacking X-Frame-Options header is not set. Neither is the Content-Security-Policy header.

An attacker could exploit this by integrating the unprotected site into a site of his own. If designed cleverly, users could be persuaded to send undesired requests to the unprotected site.

IKE Protocol Version 1
For Virtual Private Networks (VPN) the support for Internet key exchange (IKEv1) is enabled.

IKEv1 is a legacy protocol which has several security relevant disadvantages to its successor, e.g. a vulnerability to Denial-of-Service attacks.

Export Ciphers
The server supports export ciphers.

Those ciphers were designed to only provide weak security guarantees. The ciphers are very short and tend to be reused. An attacker could connect to the service herself to retrieve the key. This key then allows her to perform a man-in-the-middle attack on other users.

Short Diffie-Hellman Prime Number
The server supports SSL/TLS connections with Diffie Hellmann moduli smaller than 2048 bits.

This might allow an attacker to infer the shared secret in a short amount of time. With this secret the plaintext can be recovered.

POODLE
The server supports TLS ciphers in cipher block chaining mode, but the implemented padding check does not follow the specifications.

The deviating implementation allows an attacker to perform a POODLE attack (Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy Encryption). It allows an attacker to decipher parts of the encrypted traffic, such as session cookies. Therefore confidentiality cannot be guaranteed.

Unsorted Certificate Chain

The certificate chain is not sorted. Some CA certificate authorities publish certificate bundles that are in descending instead of ascending order, which is incorrect according to RFC 4346, Section 7.4.2 and could lead to problems in applications that process the certificate.

For more Information see:

* https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4346#section-7.4.2

Anonymous Cipher Suites

The TLS/SSL server supports anonymous cipher suites. Hence, it is possible to setup an encrypted channel with the server without verifying its identity. This renders the server vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks.

ICMP Timestamp
The system answers to ICMP timestamp requests.

This allows an attacker to read the system clock and may help him defeat time-based authentication protocols.

Null Cipher Suites
The server supports NULL cipher suites which allow setting up an unencrypted connection to the server.

An attacker can thus easily eavesdrop or manipulate the communication.

DNS Server DDoS
It is possible to query the name servers (NS) of the root zone ('.') and get an answer which is bigger than the original request.

By spoofing the source IP address, a remote attacker can leverage this 'amplification' to launch a denial-of-service attack against a third-party host using the remote DNS server.

X-Powered-By HTTP Header
The HTTP response header "X-Powered-By" reveals information about the installed product.

This facilitates a systematic search for vulnerabilities specific to that version.

HTTP Basic Authentication
The web server uses HTTP Basic Authentication for the user authentication.

In doing so, the credentials are transmitted to the server in plain text with every request.

STARTTLS Plaintext Command Injection
The SMTP service permits the injection of plaintext commands into the encrypted SMTP session.

A man-in-the-middle attacker can inject commands and with it steal a user's emails or associated Simple Authentication and Security Layer (SASL) credentials.

According to its banner, the version of OpenSSL running on the remote host is 1.0.x prior to 1.0.2m. It is, therefore, affected by an unspecified carry vulnerability.

Unsupported Windows OS

OpenSSL Vulnerabilities
According to its banner, the version of OpenSSL running on the remote host is 1.0.x prior to 1.0.2(n\|o).

These versions of OpenSSL have multiple known vulnerabilities. An attacker might perform a remote denial of service (DoS) attack, potentially recover private key information or force the software to improperly encrypt data.

RDP Publicly Reachable

Adobe Dreamweaver Information Disclosure
Adobe's Dreamweaver is known to produce 'dwsync.xml' files. These contain synchronization information that may include the list of files and directories synchronised.

This can lead to information disclosure.

SSL Session Resume

After performing a full SSL handshake to receive a session ID, it is possible to reconnect with the previously used session ID.

PhpMyAdmin Publicly Accessible
PhpMyAdmin is accessible from the internet.

OpenSSL Weak Block Cipher (SWEET32)
According to its banner, the version of OpenSSL running on the remote host is prior to 1.1.0. It is, therefore, affected by a vulnerability, known as SWEET32, in the 3DES and Blowfish algorithms due to the use of weak 64-bit block ciphers by default.

A man-in-the-middle attacker who has sufficient resources can exploit this vulnerability, via a 'birthday' attack, to detect a collision that leaks the XOR between the fixed secret and a known plaintext, allowing the disclosure of the secret text, such as secure HTTPS cookies, and possibly resulting in the hijacking of an authenticated session.

Unmaintained IIS Version

According to the server banner, a version of Microsoft-IIS/6.0 is used, which is no longer maintained.

The remote VMware ESXi host and the VMware vCenter Server in the versions 5.5.x / 6.0.x / 6.5.x / 6.7.x are affected by a speculative execution side channel attack known as L1 Terminal Fault (L1TF).

The application publishes a Flash cross-domain policy (/crossdomain.xml), which allows access from any domain. Allowing access from all domains means that any domain can perform two-way interaction with this application. Unless the application consists entirely of unprotected public content, this policy is likely to present a significant security risk.

OpenSSL Vulnerabilities
According to its banner, the version of OpenSSL running on the remote host 1.0.x prior to 1.0.2p.

HTTP TRACE Method

SSH Version in Banner

Certifi[TLS] certificate has been issued for another domain [SSL Certificate with Wrong Hostname]

Renegotiation Handshakes MiTM Data Injection

The service encrypts traffic using TLS / SSL but allows a client to renegotiate the connection after the initial handshake.

There is a Java RMI registry running on the remote host. It can be used to register and retrieve remote objects.

Terminal Service does not use NLA

The remote Terminal Services does not enforce Network Level Authentication (NLA).

NLA uses the Credential Security Support Provider (CredSSP) protocol to perform strong server authentication either through TLS/SSL or Kerberos mechanisms, which protect against man-in-the-middle attacks. In addition to improving authentication, NLA also helps protect the remote computer from malicious users and software by completing user authentication before a full RDP connection is established.

Tomcat Version on Error Page

The Apache Tomcat version is visible on the error pages. An attacker could use this information to search for vulnerabilities which are specific to that version.

Microsoft SQL Server Version Disclosure

The banner of the SQL server displays the name and the version of the used product, which facilitates a systematic search for vulnerabilities.

Microsoft SQL Server UDP Query Version Disclosure

It is possible to query the used Microsoft SQL Server version with a "ping" request.

OpenSSL AES-NI Padding Oracle

The affected service is vulnerable to a man-in-the-middle weakness caused by an error in the implementation of AES CBC ciphers.


An attacker may be able to break the encryption.

[TLS] Veraltete TLS-Version im Einsatz
Der Server unterstützt mindestens eine veraltete Version der Transport Layer Security (TLS). Diese Version wird nicht mehr unterstützt und setzt Verfahren zur Verschlüsselung ein, die nicht mehr den aktuellen Sicherheitsstandards entsprechen.

Folgende veraltete Versionen werden unterstützt:
- {{TLS 1.0}}

Ein Angreifer mit genügend Ressourcen kann unter Umständen die veraltete Verschlüsselung angreifen und dadurch die übermittelten Nachrichten auslesen.

Weitere Informationen:

> Hinweis: Diese veralteten TLS-Versionen werden von aktuellen Browsern nicht mehr unterstützt (Edge, Chrome, Firefox).

WebDAV

WebDAV, a protocol which has led to many security vulnerabilities in the past, is enabled.

Apache Tomcat Default Files

Apache Tomcat servlet/JSP default files are accessible. These should not exist on a productive system, since they expose information about the installed Tomcat version.

FTP Flaw in AUTH TLS

The remote FTP server contains a software flaw in its AUTH TLS implementation that could allow a remote unauthenticated attacker to inject commands during the plaintext protocol phase that will be executed during the ciphertext protocol phase.

For correctly validated certificates, an attacker with man-in-the-middle capabilities may be able to inject plaintext commands that will be executed during the encrypted session.

[ASVS 14.4.4] [Web] X-Content-Type-Options
Der HTTP-Header "X-Content-Type-Options" ist nicht gesetzt. Dieser Header fordert den Webbrowser auf, dem MIME-Typ zu vertrauen, der in der Serverantwort definiert ist.

Ohne diesen Header könnten Webbrowser versuchen, den MIME-Typ selbst zu erraten (MIME Sniffing). Dabei handelt es sich um ein Sicherheitsrisiko, weil ein Angreifer beispielsweise JavaScript-Code in einer Antwort platzieren könnte, deren MIME-Typ die Ausführung eigentlich verhindert. Erkennt ein Webbrowser durch MIME Sniffing den Code und führt ihn aus, ist die Applikation verwundbar auf Cross-Site Scripting (XSS).

X-XSS-Protection Header ist nicht gesetzt
Der X-XSS-Protection Header ist nicht gesetzt.

Der X-XSS-Protection Header bestimmt die Konfiguration für den bei den meisten Browsern eingebauten Cross-Site Scripting Filter und hilft daher die Applikation vor XSS-Attacken zu schützen.

HP System Management Homepage Vulnerabilities
According to its self-reported version number, the installed version of HP System Management Homepage (SMH) is suffering from multiple vulnerabilities.

The identified vulnerabilities are publicly known and can be leveraged by an attacker against the system and its users.

Cross Site Scripting (XSS)
The output encoding is flawed and susceptible to cross-site scripting attacks (XSS). Inputs that contain specific control characters are displayed by the website without appropriate character encoding. As a result, browsers may not recognize the input as a simple sequence of characters, but instead try to interpret the input as code.

Please contact Oneconsult for details as the issue cannot be presented automatically in a comprehensible way.

An attacker can inject malicious inputs containing JavaScript code, which is executed by the victim's browser.

OpenSSL Heartbleed

The OpenSSL implementation of the service is vulnerable to the Heartbleed security flaw. This vulnerability allows unauthenticated attackers to read memory data over the network.

This may lead to the disclosure of credentials, private keys or any other application data.

OpenSSL MITM Vulnerability

The present version of OpenSSL is affected by an injection vulnerability in ChangeCipherSpec (CCS) messages. An attacker can manipulate ChangeCipherSpec (CCS) messages by a man-in-the-middle attack during the session negotiation and thus lower the key strength. Using weak encryption algorithms an attacker may break the encryption and read the encrypted network traffic.

SMTP Service Cleartext Login
The SMTP server allows clear text logins over unencrypted connections.

An attacker can therefore intercept username and password.

Privacy Preferences Project (P3P) Policy
In den Serverantworten ist ersichtlich, dass die Privacy Preferences Project (P3P) Policy gesetzt ist. Die Policy wäre dafür gedacht, dem Benutzer eines Browsers aufzuzeigen, wie mit persönlichen Daten beim Besuch einer Webseite verfahren wird.

Seit dem 30. August 2018 gilt der dazugehörige Standard des World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) als veraltet und wird von modernen Browsern nicht mehr unterstützt.

[ASVS 3.4.3] [Web] Cookie SameSite-Flag
Das {{Session-}}Cookie wird ohne SameSite-Flag gesetzt. Das heisst, Webbrowser senden das Cookie auch in Anfragen mit, die in einem anderen Origin (z.B. auf einer anderen Webseite) initiiert wurden (Cross-Origin Requests).

Betroffenes Cookie:
```
{{SESSIONID | CSRF token | ...}}
```

Dieses Verhalten ermöglicht unter bestimmen Umständen Angriffe wie Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) oder Cross-Site Script Inclusion (XSSI). Dadurch können Aktionen im Kontext eines anderen Benutzers ausgeführt werden oder auf sensible Daten zugegriffen werden.

Beispiel Cookie:
```
{{Set-Cookie: ...}}
```

[ASVS] [Web] SameSite Cookie Flag
The {{session}} cookie is set without the "SameSite" flag. Without this flag, web browsers send the cookie with every request, even if it was initiated by another domain (cross-origin requests).

Affected cookie:
```
{{SESSIONID | CSRF token | etc. }}
```

This simplifies Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) and Cross-Site Script Inclusion (XSSI) under special circumstances. Consequently, the absence of the flag could be exploited to perform actions on another user's behalf or to access sensitive data.

Sample cookie:
```
{{Set-Cookie: ...}}
```

[TLS] CBC Chiffren TLS 1.2
Der Server unterstützt TLS-Chiffren, die den Verschlüsselungsmodus "Cipher Block Chaining" (CBC-Modus) benutzen.

Betroffene Chiffren:
```
{{CHIFFRE}}
```

Der CBC-Modus in der TLS-Version 1.2 weist Schwachstellen auf, welche mit Padding-Orakel-Angriffen wie Zombie POODLE und GOLDENDOODLE ausgenutzt werden können. Diese Angriffe könnten es Angreifern ermöglichen, unter gewissen Umständen Teile der übermittelten Daten zu entschlüsseln.

Weitere Informationen:
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/security/vulnerabilities-cbc-mode
* https://www.tripwire.com/state-of-security/vulnerability-management/zombie-poodle-goldendoodle

[TLS] CBC Ciphers Supported in TLS 1.2
The server supports ciphers that are used in the "Cipher Block Chaining" mode (CBC mode).

Relevant ciphers:
```
{{CIPHER}}
```

The CBC mode in TLS version 1.2 introduces vulnerabilities that can be exploited with padding oracle attacks such as Zombie POODLE and GOLDENDOODLE. Under certain circumstances, these attacks could allow attackers to decrypt parts of the transmitted data.

Further information:
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/security/vulnerabilities-cbc-mode
* https://www.tripwire.com/state-of-security/vulnerability-management/zombie-poodle-goldendoodle

[SSH Config] Stream local forwarding enabled
The server currently allows StreamLocalForwarding.

This allows any attacker with access to ssh to open Unix domain sockets on the server and transmitting the content to the attacker.

No D/Q/P environment
There is only a productive environment and no testing nor quality-assurance environment.

Not having a separated development and quality environment can have a critical security impact. New services have to be tested on the productive environment which does not only endanger the availability of productive services but also exposes potential security risks present in untestet or unhardened products.

Furthermore, every project team member need access to the productive environment and it is thus not possible to limit the access to only few chosen individuals.

Currently set options:

\<Directory /\>

AllowOverride None

Require all denied

[BETA] Zertifikatssignatur unzureichend
Das TLS-Zertifikat ist entweder selbstsigniert, auf einen anderen Hostnamen ausgestellt oder es wurde von einer unbekannten Zertifizierungsstelle herausgegeben.

Kommunikationspartner müssen das Zertifikat ignorieren, um trotzdem eine Verbindung mit dem System aufbauen zu können. Das heisst, die Echtheit des Systems wird nicht mehr verifiziert. Das vereinfacht Man-in-the-Middle-Angriffe beträchtlich.


Bemerkung: Webbrowser generieren bei ungültigen Zertifikaten eine Sicherheitswarnung. Benutzer können diese Warnung ignorieren, was in der Praxis sehr oft geschieht. Da die meisten Benutzer ein abgelaufenes Zertifikat jedoch nicht von einem gefälschten unterscheiden können, sind sie einem erhöhten Sicher-heitsrisiko ausgesetzt.

Auslesen von Passworthashes mit IPMI v2.0
Der Server unterstützt das Protokol "Intelligent Platform Management Interface" (IPMI v2.0). IPMI v2.0 nutzt für die Authentifizierung das Protokoll RAKP, welches anfragenden Clients den Passworthash mitteilt.

Ein Angreifer kann versuchen, mithilfe eines Brute-Force- oder Wörterbuchangriffs das Passwort aus dem übermittelten Passworthash abzuleiten. Das Passwort kann für weitere Angriffe auf Dienste verwendet werden, die IPMI nutzen.

IKEv1-Schwachstelle in Cisco-Gerät
Das Cisco-Gerät nutzt das Protokoll "Internet Key Exchange version 1" (IKEv1). Die Software verarbeitet IKEv1-Pakete jedoch fehlerhaft. Das Resultat ist eine Schwachstelle, die als "BENIGNCERTAIN" bekannt ist.


Relevante CVE:

* CVE-2016-6415


Ein Angreifer kann diese Schwachstelle ausnutzen, um an sensible Daten wie Passwörter oder Konfigurationen zu gelangen.

Nginx Vulnerabilities
Based on its banner, the version of Nginx running on this system is suffering from multiple vulnerabilities.

SSH Diffie-Hellman Modulus <= 1024 Bits (Logjam)
The remote host allows SSH connections with one or more Diffie-Hellman moduli less than or equal to 1024 bits.

Through cryptanalysis, a third party can find the shared secret in a short amount of time (depending on modulus size and attacker resources). This allows an attacker to recover the plaintext or potentially violate the integrity of connections.

TCP/IP Sequence Prediction Blind Reset Spoofing DoS
The remote host is affected by a sequence number approximation vulnerability.

This allows an attacker to send spoofed RST packets to the remote host and close established connections. This may cause problems for some dedicated services (BGP, a VPN over TCP, etc).

Default nginx HTTP Server Settings
The remote webserver contains default settings such as enabled server tokens and/or default files such as the default index or error pages.

These items could potentially leak useful information about the server installation.
Error Page Information Disclosure

Webserver Default Index Page
The web server presents its default index page. This page may contain sensitive information such as the web server's root and installation paths or version information.

This can be of value to an attacker and make it easier to identify the installed version of the server or use the information to easier execute an exploit on the system.

[WordPress] Öffentliches WordPress-Login
Die Benutzeranmeldung von WordPress ist öffentlich erreichbar.

Dadurch wird die Angriffsfläche des Systems unnötig vergrössert. Ein Angreifer kann beispielsweise Brute-Force-Angriffe auf Benutzernamen oder Passwörter durchführen. Mit gültigen Anmeldedaten könnte er sich anmelden und die Applikation manipulieren.

URL:
* {{https://example.com/wp-login.php }}

[WordPress] WordPress login public
The WordPress login is publicly available.

This increases the system's attack surface considerably. An adversary could carry out brute-force attacks against usernames and passwords. With valid credentials, he could login and manipulate the web application.

URL:
* {{https://example.com/wp-login.php}}

[Web] XML External Entity Injection
The XML parser of the application processes "XML External Entities" (XXE), which means referenced files and resources are embedded into the corresponding XML document. This renders the application vulnerable to XXE injection.

An adversary could exploit this issue to access arbitrary resources on the file system (as long as the XML parser has reading permissions). Under special circumstances, XXE injection can enable an adversary to execute code and compromise the system.

For an example and further information, please see {{chapter TODO}}.

[ASVS 14.4.6] [Web] Referrer Policy
Der HTTP-Header "Referrer-Policy" ist nicht gesetzt. Die Webapplikation überlässt somit die Entscheidung, welche Informationen im HTTP-Header "Referer" gesendet werden, dem Webbrowser. Der Referer-Header in der HTTP-Anfrage teilt dem Webserver mit, in welchem Origin die Anfrage abgesetzt wurde.

> Hinweis: Beim Header-Namen "Referer" handelt es sich um eine falsche Schreibweise von "Referrer", die auf die ursprüngliche Implementierung zurückgeht und auch so in die Standardisierung (RFC-1945) übernommen wurde.
Ohne eine Referrer Policy besteht die Gefahr, dass Webbrowser beim Aufrufen eines Links die vollständige URL der Ursprungsseite an den Server schicken. Dadurch kann die Privatsphäre von Benutzern und die Vertraulichkeit von sensiblen Informationen gefährdet werden. So könnte der Zielserver anhand des Referer-Headers beispielsweise erkennen, ob der Benutzer ein Konto auf der vorherigen Seite hat. Falls die URL sensible Informationen enthält, können diese ebenfalls ausgelesen werden.

[ASVS 14.4.6] [Web] Referrer Policy
The "Referrer-Policy" HTTP header is not set by the web server. This leaves the decision on what information to send in the "Referer" header to web browsers. This header is used to pass information about the origin of the previous website to the next one.

>Note: The header name "Referer" is an incorrect spelling of "Referrer", which goes back to the original implementation and was also included as such in the standardization (RFC-1945).
Without a referrer policy, web browsers might pass the entire URL of the previous site to the web server whenever users follow a link. This might endanger the users' privacy and the confidentiality of user-related data. For example, the target web application might be able to deduce, based on the URL, whether a user has an account on the previous website or not. If the URL contains sensitive information, it is disclosed as well.

[Web] Cross-Origin Resource Sharing mit Credentials
Der Webserver setzt den folgenden HTTP-Header und vereinfacht damit Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS):
```
Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: true
```

Wenn Skriptcode eines anderen Origins (beispielsweise JavaScript auf einer Drittseite) eine Anfrage an die Webapplikation schickt, erlaubt der Webbrowser dem aufrufenden Code, die Antwort des Webservers zu lesen. Mit dem oben erwähnten Header gilt das auch für Anfragen, die mit Credentials (also beispielsweise mit Sitzungstoken) abgesetzt wurden.

Ein Angreifer könnte unter Umständen zu sensiblen Informationen gelangen, die nur der angemeldete Benutzer sehen sollte. Dazu müssen die folgenden Voraussetzungen erfüllt sein:
- Die Anfrage kommt aus einem Origin, der durch den HTTP-Header "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" erlaubt ist.
- Der HTTP-Header "Access-Control-Allow-Credentials" ist für diese Anfrage auf "true" gesetzt.
- Der angegriffene Benutzer besucht die entsprechende Webseite, auf welcher der bösartige Skriptcode eingebunden wurde.

Betroffene Anfragen:
```
{{Anfragen hier, falls nur Ausnahmen betroffen sind}}
```

[Web] HTTP Public Key Pinning
The web server sets the HTTP header "Public-Key-Pins" to use HTTP Public Key Pinning (HPKP). HPKP is a security feature that tells a web client to associate a specific public key with a certain domain.

Even though HPKP reduces the chance of successful man-in-the-middle attacks, it poses a security risk itself. Once clients have stored the pin, the server is forced to stick to the pinned key. If a compromised private key, an expired certificate, or a configuration mistake make changes to the key material inevitable, users relying on the out-dated pin will not be able to access the web application anymore (denial-of-service).

[Windows Client] Unnötige eingehende Firewall Regeln (öffentlich)
Die Windows Defender Firewall besitzt für das öffentliche Profil mehrere erlaubte Firewall-Regeln, welche möglicherweise nicht verwendet werden.

Die Regeln erhöhen in einem öffentlichen WLAN oder sonstigen öffentlichen Netz unnötig die Angriffsfläche.

[Windows Client] Web Proxy Autodiscovery Protocol (WPAD) ist aktiv
Das für die automatische Proxy-Konfiguration zuständige Protokoll WPAD ist aktiviert.

Wenn sich das Gerät in einem öffentlichen Netzwerk befindet, birgt dies ein Risiko bzgl. Man-in-the-Middle (MitM)-Angriffen. Zudem lässt sich der NTLMv2-Hash des angemeldeten Benutzers ermitteln, auch wenn das Gerät gesperrt ist.

Das Notebook verfügt über zwei USB-C-Ports, bei denen Thunderbolt 3 ohne Schutzfunktionen aktiviert ist.

[Windows Client] HP SureStart nicht eingerichtet
HP SureStart kontrolliert und überprüft vor jedem Bootvorgang, ob Änderungen im BIOS geschrieben wurden und besitzt damit die Möglichkeit, Manipulationen am BIOS zu detektieren und rückgängig zu machen. Falls eine manipulierte BIOS-Version erkannt wird, wird das aktuelle BIOS mit einer Kopie der gesicherten Version automatisch ersetzt und wiederhergestellt.

Da diese Funkionalität nicht aktiviert ist, wird auf diesen spezifischen Schutz vor BIOS-Manipulationen verzichtet.

Cross-Origin Resource Sharing With Credentials
The "Access-Control-Allow-Credentials" HTTP header is set to "true". This simplifies Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS).

If an external script (e.g. JavaScript from an external site) sends a request to the web application, the browser allows this script to read the server response.

If the above-mentioned header is used, this is also possible for requests using a session token (authenticated requests).

Under certain circumstances, an attacker might gain access to sensitive information only an authenticated user should see. To achieve this, the following requirements must be met:

- The request must come from an origin that is allowed by the "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" HTTP header.

- The "Access-Control-Allow-Credentials" HTTP header must be set to "true" for this request.

- The attacked user must access the website where the malicious script code was embedded.

Affected requests:
- {{REQUESTS}}

Rancher Web Parameter Tampering
A vulnerable version of Rancher (before 2.2.4) is running. This version has a web parameter tampering vulnerability.

An attacker can display arbitrary content to the user on the login page. This could be used to lure a user to a phishing site or as part of a social engineering attack.

IP Forwarding
The system has IP forwarding enabled.

An attacker can exploit this to route packets through the system and potentially bypass network level filtering.

DNS Response Flooding DoS

It is possible to spoof DNS packets such that they appear to come from 127.0.0.1 and make the DNS server enter into an infinite loop. This may lead to the DNS server denying service to legitimate users.

DNS Cache Snooping Attacks

The DNS server responds to queries for third-party domains which do not have the recursion bit set. This may allow a remote attacker to determine which domains have recently been resolved via this name server, and therefore which hosts have been recently visited (DNS cache snooping).

Dies erlaubt es einem Angreifer, auf sämtliche Daten auf der Festplatte zuzugreifen. Risiken bestehen insbesondere bei ge-stohlenen, verlorenen oder nicht ordnungsgemäss ausser Dienst gestellten Geräten.

[Windows Client] Device Guard nicht aktiv
Der Microsoft Device Guard ist deaktiviert.

Durch die virtualisierungsbasierte Sicherheit (VBS) kann verhindert werden, dass sich Schadsoftware leicht im Kernel einnistet. Auch ist das Gerät dadurch besser gegen DMA-Angriffe (Direct Memory Access) geschützt.

Zusätzlich ist es möglich, durch die Codeintegritätsrichtlinien eine Whitelist mit zulässiger Software zu erstellen.

[Windows Client] Credential Guard nicht aktiviert

Pulse Connect Secure Vulnerabilities

It is suffering from multiple vulnerabilities.

Cisco IOS IKEv1 Information Disclosure
The remote Cisco device is affected by a known information disclosure vulnerability due to improper handling of IKEv1 security negotiation requests.

This allows an unauthenticated, remote attacker to send a specially crafted IKEv1 packet and receive potentially confidential information like credentials and configuration settings.

TCP Hijacking
The initial sequence number (ISN) of received TCP packets is not random and can be predicted.

An attacker could exploit this to take over TCP connections through a man-in-the-middle attack (TCP Hijacking).

Microsoft RDP RCE (BlueKeep)
The host is affected by a critical RDP Pre-Authentication Remote Code Execution vulnerability.

This may allow attackers to run arbitrary malware on an affected system without prior authentication or interaction of a legitimate user. Microsoft itself compares this vulnerability with the SMB vulnerability of 2017 (MS17-010), which was exploited by WannaCry, for example. The security vulnerability at hand has a similar potential to be exploited and thus cause great damage.

Affected operating systems are: Windows 7, Windows 2008 R2, Windows 2008, Windows 2003, Windows XPNot affected: Windows Server 2012, Windows Server 2012 R2, Windows Server 2016, Windows Server 2019, Windows 8, Windows 8.1, Windows 10

[Advanced Mail Test] MTA-STS nicht umgesetzt

[Advanced Mail Test] Benutzer können E-Mails aus Quarantäne freigeben

Dadurch könnten Benutzer unwissentlich bösartige E-Mails freigeben.

IBM AIX TCP Large Send Denial of Service Vulnerability
IBM AIX is known to have a vulnerability that allows an attacker to perform denial-of-service attacks.

By sending specially crafted packets, an attacker might exploit this vulnerability and cause a kernel panic. To make this attack possible, the option "TCP large send offload" needs to be enabled.

Firewall UDP Packet Source Port 53 Ruleset Bypass
It is possible to bypass the rules of the firewall by sending UDP packets with the source port 53.

An attacker might use this to inject UDP packets to the remote host and bypass the firewall.

Firewall UDP Packet Source Port 53 Ruleset Bypass
Es ist möglich, die Regeln der Firewall zu umgehen, indem man UDP-Pakete mit dem Source-Port 53 sendet.

Ein Angreifer kann dies verwenden, um UDP-Pakete an der Firewall vorbei an den Host zu senden. Somit wird die Funktion der Firewall umgangen.

IBM AIX TCP Large Send Denial of Service Vulnerability
IBM AIX ist anfällig für einen Angriff, der es Angreifern ermöglicht, Denial-of-Service-Zustände auf dem Host zu verursachen.

Durch das Senden von speziell gestalteten Paketen kann ein Angreifer diese Schwachstelle ausnutzen und damit eine Kernelpanik verursachen. Um diesen Angriff zu ermöglichen, muss die Option "TCP large send offload" aktiviert sein.

Multiple BSD ipfw / ip6fw ECE Bit Filtering Evasion
The host is affected by a bug when setting the ECE bit within the TCP flags field.

The bug allows an remote attacker to circumvent the firewall.

BSD ipfw / ip6fw ECE Bit: Umgehen von Filtermechanismen
Der Service ist anfällig für einen Bug, wenn das ECE-Bit innerhalb des TCP-Flag-Feldes gesetzt ist.

Durch Ausnutzen dieses Bugs ist es unauthentifizierten Angreifern möglich, die Filtermechanismen der Firewall zu umgehen.

TCP/IP Initial Sequence Number (ISN) Reuse Weakness
The remote host seems to generate Initial Sequence Numbers (ISN) in a weak manner which seems to solely depend on the source and destination port of the TCP packets.

An attacker may exploit this flaw to establish spoofed connections to the remote host.

The Raptor Firewall and Novell NetWare are known to be vulnerable to this flaw, although other network devices may be vulnerable as well.

TCP/IP Initial Sequence Number (ISN) Reuse Weakness 
Der Host scheint Initial Sequence Numbers (ISN) auf eine unsichere Weise zu erzeugen, die ausschließlich vom Quell- und Destination-Port der TCP-Pakete abhängt.

Ein Angreifer kann diesen Fehler ausnutzen, um gespoofte Verbindungen zum Remote-Host herzustellen.

IPMI Cipher Suite Zero Authentication Bypass
The IPMI service listening on the remote system has cipher suite zero enabled, which permits logon as an administrator without requiring a password.

Once logged in, a remote attacker may perform a variety of actions, including powering off the remote system.

IPMI Cipher Suite Zero Authentication Bypass 
Der IPMI-Dienst hat den Verschlüsselungsmodus "zero" aktiviert, was eine Anmeldung als Administrator ohne Passwort ermöglicht.

Nach der Anmeldung kann ein entfernter Angreifer eine Reihe von Aktionen ausführen, einschließlich des Ausschaltens des Systems.

Dangerous CGI Script Detection
The remote web server may contain some dangerous CGI scripts.

These default CGI scripts that are usually included in outdated default installations, can contain dangerous functionalities which might allow an attacker to execute commands, sniff passwords, or bypass restrictions.

The exact risks are depended on the corresponding CGI script.

Potenziell gefährliche CGI-Skripte
Der Webserver enthält unter Umständen gefährliche CGI-Skripte.

Standard-CGI-Skripte, die teilweise in veralteten Standardinstallationen von Webservern enthalten sind, können gefährliche Funktionalitäten enthalten, die es einem Angreifer ermöglichen, Befehle auszuführen, Passwörter auszulesen oder Einschränkungen zu umgehen.
Die genauen Risiken sind abhängig vom jeweiligen CGI-Skript.

Disclosure of Hashes With IPMI v2.0
The server supports the Intelligent Platform Management Interface protocol (IPMI v2.0). IPMI v2.0 uses the RAKP protocol for authentication, which notifies requesting clients of the password hash.

An attacker can attempt to derive the password from the transmitted password hash using a brute-force or dictionary attack. The password can be used for further attacks on services that use IPMI.

VxWorks WDB Debug-Service
The VxWorks WDB Debug-Service is running on the host.

An attacker might use this service to read an arbitrary amount of memory or to execute code on the system. Therefore, a complete takeover of the system would be possible.

VxWorks WDB Debug-Service
Der VxWorks WDB Debug-Service läuft auf dem System.

Ein Angreifer könnte diesen verwenden, um beliebigen Speicher auszulesen oder Code auf dem System auszuführen und somit die Kontrolle über das System zu übernehmen.

[Windows Client] Secure Boot

These requests can be used to read information from the database or to manipulate data sets. As a result, this can lead to compromised user accounts, manipulated business processes or the compromise of the server itself.

Legacy SSL/TLS version in use
The server supports a legacy version of the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) or Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. This version uses encryption schemes that do not provide the same security guarantees as the current standard.

An attacker with sufficient resources can, under certain conditions, attack the legacy encryption and therefore read the transmitted messages.

Further information:

* https://blog.pcisecuritystandards.org/are-you-ready-for-30-june-2018-sayin-goodbye-to-ssl-early-tls
* https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2018/10/15/removing-old-versions-of-tls/
* https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2018/10/15/modernizing-tls-edge-ie11/
* https://security.googleblog.com/2018/10/modernizing-transport-security.html

Note: All major browser vendors have announced that they will no longer support TLS 1.0 and 1.1 from 2020.

BIND reveals host name and server version

The remote host is running BIND, an open-source DNS server. It is possible to extract the hostname and the version number of the remote installation by sending a special DNS request for the TXT record 'hostname.bind' and 'version.bind' in the domain 'chaos'.

Tenable Nessus Vulnerabilities
According to its self-reported version number, the installed version of Tenable Nessus is outdated.

It is suffering from multiple vulnerabilities.

Fortinet FertiOS Vulnerabilities
According to its self-reported version number, the installed version of Fortinet FertiOS is outdated.

It is suffering from multiple vulnerabilities.

[TLS] TLS 1.3 nicht unterstützt
Der Webserver unterstützt TLS 1.3 nicht.

Das Protokoll bietet im Vergleich zur Vorgängerversion 1.2 eine erhöhte Sicherheit sowie Verbesserungen in den Bereichen Vertraulichkeit und Performance.

> Hinweis: Wenn nur TLS 1.2 verwendet wird, ergibt sich daraus bei entsprechender Konfiguration kein unmittelbares Sicherheitsrisiko. Um jedoch auch zukünftig die Kompatibilität und Sicherheit der Anwendung sicherzustellen, sollte TLS 1.3 aktiviert werden.

[TLS] TLS 1.3 Not Supported
The web server does not support TLS 1.3.

The protocol offers increased security compared to the previous version 1.2 as well as improvements in the areas of confidentiality and performance.

> Note: If only TLS 1.2 is used, there is no immediate security risk. However, to ensure the compatibility and security of the application in the future, TLS 1.3 should be enabled.

JavaScript Library Outdated
The web application uses an outdated JavaScript library.

The vulnerable JavaScript library could be exploited by an attacker against users of the web application.

Missing Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) Protection
The web form does not have apparent anti-CSRF protections implemented.

Potentially not all actions in the application are protected against cross-site request forgery (CSRF). This means that an attacker may execute arbitrary actions in the name of a currently logged in user by making the user visit a specially crafted rogue webpage.

Development Configuration File
A development configuration file was found.

Such files may expose sensitive information that could help attackers to prepare more advanced attacks.

Dictionary or Brute-Force Attack
Between multiple login attempts no restrictions are enforced against password-guessing attacks.

Therefore it is possible to crack account passwords with a dictionary or brute-force attack against the server.

No Content Security Policy (CSP)
The HTTP header "Content-Security-Policy" is not set. A content security policy (CSP) can be regarded as an additional hardening measure that protects the web application against many client-side attacks such as cross-site scripting (XSS), clickjacking, or loading malicious content.

If an attacker finds a vulnerability in a web application that is not protected with a CSP, he can exploit it more easily.

Content-Type Missing
DELETE

DELETE

Detailed Error Information
Responses contain stack traces or other detailed error information if an error occurs.

Technical information is not supposed to be visible to clients as it does not provide any added value. To an attacker however, this information might give valuable hints as to which frameworks and libraries are used by the web application. Apart from that, technical details can help in the analysis of errors and simplify the search for security issues.

Reflected Cross-Site Scripting
User input is reflected without sufficient encoding in the web server's responses. Consequently, web browsers interpret certain symbols as control characters and not as text.

This makes the application vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) and HTML injection. An adversary could embed HTML or JavaScript code into the web application, which is interpreted or executed in the web browser of an attacked user, respectively.

Credentials are Visible in the URL
The credentials are sent as HTTP GET parameters during the login process.

Sensitive information should never be part of the URL because web servers, proxies and browsers may log, cache or bookmark them. Additionally, this information may be read out via scripts from browser history or be transferred to third parties as part of the HTTP Referrer header.

[Web] Unsichere Speicherung Access-Token im Browser
Die folgende Token werden im lokalen Speicher des Browsers ("sessionStorage") gespeichert:
- {{Access-Token (JSON Web Token)}}

Dies hat im Vergleich zu klassischen Cookies mehrere Nachteile:
- Die Daten im lokalen Speicher des Browsers können durch JavaScript-Code gelesen und verändert werden, was ein Angreifer bei einer Cross-Site-Scripting-Attacke nutzen kann, um an das Token zu gelangen. Im Gegensatz dazu lassen sich Cookies mit dem httpOnly-Flag vor JavaScript-Zugriff schützen.
- Die Daten im lokalen Speicher des Browsers können nicht weiter isoliert werden. Der Zugriff auf den lokalen Speicher ist jeweils für alle Applikationen aus dem "Same-Origin" möglich. Dazu gehören aber unter Umständen auch JavaScript Code, der von Drittparteien nachgeladen wird, wie z.B. Tracking-Code oder Analytic- oder Advertising-Code, womit Drittpartien Zugriff auf diese Token erhalten.

Dadurch kann das Token leichter kompromittiert werden.

SMS wird für Zwei-Faktor-Authentisierung (2FA) verwendet
Das One-Time Password (OTP) wird über SMS versendet.

SMS weist bekannte Schwachstellen auf, die es einem Angreifer ermöglichen können, die SMS mit den Login-Codes mitzuschneiden.

Weitere Informationen:
→ https://www.theguardian.com/money/2015/sep/26/sim-swap-fraud-mobile-phone-vodafone-customer

[mobile] Android app marked as debuggable in the AndroidManifest.xml file 

The Android app is marked as "debuggable" in the AndroidManifest.xml file. Debuggable apps make it easier for an attacker to analyze and may facilitate attacks on the app.

AndroidManifest.xml:

XXXXXX

\<application android:allowBackup="true" android:appComponentFactory="androidx.core.app.CoreComponentFactory" **android:debuggable="true"**

**XXXXXX**

Further information:

http://developer.android.com/guide/topics/manifest/application-element.html#debug

[Config Review] No Log Policies

The monitoring (logging) settings are the default settings from Microsoft.
In case of a forensic investigation, important clues will be missing.

DNS-Pingback
Über den "XXXX"-Header wird ein DNS-Pingback auf die angegebene URL durchgeführt.

Das Verhalten an sich stellt nicht zwingend ein Sicherheitsrisiko dar, deutet in vielen Fällen jedoch auf weitere Sicherheitslücken hin. Dazu zählt z.B. eine Open-Redirect-Verwundbarkeit.

Fehlende Authentisierung für die API
Fehlende Authentisierung für die API


Aktuell gibt es keine Authentisierung für die \<API-NAME\>-API.
Dies erlaubt es einem Angreifer, beliebige Daten zu editieren und zu löschen. Hierdurch könnte er Fehlinformationen verbreiten

Missing Authentication for the API 
Missing Authentication for the API

Currently there is no authentication necessary for the \<API-NAME\> API. This would allow an attacker to change data and spread misinformation

Password Change Not Possible
Users cannot change their passwords on their own.

If a user learns that his password has been compromised, he will not be able to react immediately and set a new password. The possible time window for an attacker is thus extended.
Furthermore, a user cannot replace his existing password with a stronger one by himself.

Password Change Without Old Password
It is possible to change the password of the user account without entering the old password.

If an attacker is able to take over a user's session (e.g. by stealing the session token), they can persist their access to the user's account by setting a new password.

Pasting passwords not supported
It is not possible to insert passwords in the corresponding field of the login mask.

Users who use password managers are forced to type their randomly generated passwords manually. This can lead to them deliberately choosing weaker passwords that are easier to enter.

Passwords Not Checked Against Breaches
When the user sets a new password, the system does not check whether it is a known compromised password.

This allows users to choose passwords that appear in lists of compromised passwords. Attackers use such lists to compromise user accounts via dictionary attacks or password spraying.

[Web] Mangelhafte serverseitige Zugriffskontrolle
Die Webapplikation führt die Zugriffskontrolle {{bei gewissen Funktionen}} nur auf dem Client durch, jedoch nicht auf dem Server. Diese client-seitige Zugriffskontrolle kann jedoch manipuliert und umgangen werden.

Ein Angreifer kann dadurch Funktionen aufrufen oder Datenzugriffe und Aktionen durchführen, zu denen er nicht berechtigt wäre.

{{Beispielsweise prüft die Applikation auf dem Client, ob ein Benutzer über Administratorenrechte verfügt. Ist dies nicht der Fall, so wird der entsprechende Reiter ausgegraut. Ein authentifizierter, unprivilegierter Angreifer kann jedoch die Funktionsaufrufe durch Analyse des Codes der Webseite selbst konstruieren und Funktionen aufrufen, die für Administratoren bestimmt sind.}}

[Web] Manipulation der Benutzerprivilegien
Die Applikation speichert Informationen über die Privilegien des authentifizierten Benutzers {{in kodierter Form im Sitzungscookie/im Parameter "scope"/"isAdmin" des Sitzungstokens}}. Diese Informationen sind jedoch nicht gegen Manipulation geschützt.

Ein authentifizierter Angreifer kann diese Informationen manipulieren um sich erhöhte Zugriffsrechte zu verschaffen.

Apache Tomcat AJP Request Injection
A file read and file inclusion vulnerability exists in the Apache Tomcat AJP Connector.

This vulnerability allows a remote, unauthenticated attacker to read files on the vulnerable server. In case the web application allows users to upload files, it is likely that an attack is able to remotely execute arbitrary code on the affected system.

System on Extended Support
According to its self-reported version number, the identified system runs a Unix/Linux operating system on extended support.

Access to new security updates is only available for a fee and/or by changing the configuration of the package manager. Without these security updates, the system will become increasingly vulnerable over time.

Open Mail Relaying
The SMTP server allows unauthorized users to send emails with an arbitrary sender address (name@domain.com) to an arbitrary recipient address (name2@domain2.com). This is referred to as email relaying und spoofing.

An attacker could exploit this by sending for example spam emails through the affected system. Such system abuse may lead to the server being added to well-known blacklists, which may negatively impact email communication with the outside world.

[Windows Client] Java security level configuration
Oracle Java is configured so that Java content is enabled by default for browser and Web Start applications and that applications can run even if their certificate status ("revoked status") cannot be verified.

As a result, there is a risk that code could be executed from potentially compromised sources.

[Windows Client] Java "Native Sandbox" is not activated
In Oracle Java the "operating system's restricted environment (native sandbox)" is not activated.

This could allow malicious Java applications to access other applications or services running outside the sandbox.

[Windows Client] Acrobat Reader security function not activated
Adobe Acrobat Reader does not have "Protected View" enabled.

If this option is deactivated, certain PDF functions are enabled. This increases the risk of potential threats from files from insecure sources.

[Windows Client] Java allows use of outdated TLS versions
Oracle Java is configured to allow applications to use TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 for secure connections.

These versions use encryption methods that no longer comply with current security standards. An attacker with sufficient resources can, under certain conditions, attack the legacy encryption and therefore read the transmitted messages.

For further information, see:

* https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2018/10/15/removing-old-versions-of-tls/
* https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2018/10/15/modernizing-tls-edge-ie11/
* https://security.googleblog.com/2018/10/modernizing-transport-security.html

Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) via SMS
As a second authentication factor for logging into the application, a one-time password is sent to the stored mobile number by SMS.
SMS should not be used because this technology has known weaknesses.

Examples of possible attacks:

* Codes may appear in the notification screen when the device is locked
* Malicious mobile applications could intercept the SMS messages
* Social engineering of the mobile phone provider (SIM swapping)
* Attacks on Signalling System Number 7 (SS7) protocols

Two-factor authentication (2FA) via email
As a second authentication factor for logging into the application, a one-time password is sent to the e-mail address associated with the user account.

This method is not considered a second factor, because access to an e-mail mailbox does not prove ownership of a particular device.

Examples of possible attacks:
* E-mail may be sent unencrypted
* Attacks with spoofed e-mails
* Attacks on the e-mail provider
* Exploiting (weak) e-mail access data

The CRL of the CA is not retrievable
To check, if a certificate has been revoked by the issuing CA, a client may retrieve a Certificate Revocation List (CRL). According the certificate information, the CRL is available for download using {{Protokolle auflisten, z.B. HTTP, LDAP}}. However, during the audit the CRL could not be downloaded with {{either}} protocol.


A client cannot determine wether a certificate has been revoked or not. Therefore, the client may accept an invalid certificate

[Windows Client] Private key not protected by the TPM
To authenticate against the server, clients must own a certificate. The private key of the certificate is not protected by the TPM.

This poses a risk that the private key can be read by malware.

[Windows Client] Privater Schlüssel wird nicht vom TPM geschützt
Um sich gegenüber dem VPN-Endpunkt zu authentifizieren, müssen Clients ein Zertifikat aufweisen. Der Privatekey des Zertifikats wird dabei nicht durch das TPM geschützt.

Somit besteht die Gefahr, dass der Privatekey durch Malware ausgelesen werden kann.

Reflected HTTP Parameter Pollution
The application uses user-provided data in an insecure manner to construct URLs and therefore is vulnerable to HTTP parameter pollution. An attacker can abuse this behavior to prepare a URL that, when visited, modifies the URLs within the response by adding additional query parameters. Moreover, existing parameters can be overwritten.

This way, a user may be tricked to unwillingly visit a specific URL.
