Max-Age HSTS
The server uses HTTPS and the "max-age" value of the 
"Strict-Transport-Security" (HSTS) HTTP header is set to {{2592000}}. This header is a hardening measure that enforces secure connections to the server in web browsers.

The "max-age" value defines how long the HSTS header is valid for a domain. Due to misconfiguration, the HSTS header might not be set in future responses. In this case, this hardening measure would only be valid for {{2592000 seconds (=30 days)}} after a user visited the domain.

Without HSTS, web browsers allow unencrypted connections to the web server, which do not verify the web server's authenticity. This makes web browsers susceptible to man-in-the-middle attacks, in which attackers could intercept and manipulate data.

Further information:
- https://www.owasp.org/index.php/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security

Email Password Reset / Identity Proofing
Email-based password reset methods are only recommended for low-risk applications where the data involved is not highly sensitive. Additionally, the identity proofing during the restoration of an account (for a lost password) does not seem to be the same as during enrollment{ as this process is carried out by XXX staff}.
The following are some of the weaknesses of this method:
►	The reset token is sent over a potentially insecure channel (email).
►	The identity of the person asking and receiving the reset is not ensured as access to an inbox does not proof ownership of it.

Therefore, an attacker who obtains the reset link, via a compromised email address or by sniffing network traffic, will obtain access to the application as no further checks are made. As this application works with highly sensitive data, the security requirements for this application are high. Therefore, the email-based reset is insufficient.

No Measures Against Dependency Confusion
The repository is missing countermeasures against a dependency confusion attack.



Without countermeasures, an attacker could carry out a so-called dependency confusion attack under certain circumstances.

In this attack, a malicious package with the same name as a private package is published with a higher version number than the private one. 

Due to this, the package manager could choose the malicious public package with the higher version number instead of the private package, which can lead to remote code execution (RCE).

Further information:
* https://medium.com/@alex.birsan/dependency-confusion-4a5d60fec610

Keine Maßnahmen gegen Dependency Confusion
Dem Repository fehlen Gegenmaßnahmen gegen einen Dependency Confusion Angriff.
Ohne Gegenmaßnahmen könnte ein Angreifer unter bestimmten Umständen einen so genannten Dependency Confusion Angriff durchführen.

Bei diesem Angriff wird ein bösartiges Paket mit demselben Namen wie ein privates Paket veröffentlicht. Dieses erhält allerdings eine höheren Versionsnummer, als das private Paket.

Dadurch könnte der Paketmanager das bösartige öffentliche Paket mit der höheren Versionsnummer anstelle des privaten Pakets auswählen, was zu einer remote code execution (RCE) führen kann.

Weitere Informationen:
* https://medium.com/@alex.birsan/dependency-confusion-4a5d60fec610

[API] Content-Security-Policy (CSP)
Der HTTP-Header "Content-Security-Policy" ist nicht gesetzt. Eine Content Security Policy (CSP) ist eine Härtungsmassnahme, welche die API gegen clientseitige Angriffe schützt.

Ohne eine CSP ist die API möglicherweise auf Drag-and-Drop Clickjacking Angriffe anfällig, in welchen der Angreifer versucht, den Benutzer mittels eines unsichtbaren Inline-Frames zu einer Drag-and-Drop Aktion zu bewegen, welche dem Angreifer Zugriff auf die API-Antwort geben könnte.

Weitere Informationen:
- https://www.w3.org/Security/wiki/Clickjacking_Threats#Drag_and_drop_attacks

[API] X-Frame-Options
Der HTTP-Header "X-Frame-Options" ist nicht gesetzt. Der X-Frame-Options-Header ist wie der CSP-Header eine Härtungsmassnahme, welche die API gegen clientseitige Angriffe schützt.

Ohne den X-Frame-Options-Header ist die API möglicherweise auf Drag-and-Drop-Clickjacking-Angriffe anfällig, in welchen der Angreifer versucht, den Benutzer mittels eines unsichtbaren Inline-Frames zu einer Drag-and-Drop-Aktion zu bewegen, welche dem Angreifer Zugriff auf die API-Antwort geben könnte.

Weitere Informationen:
- https://www.w3.org/Security/wiki/Clickjacking_Threats#Drag_and_drop_attacks

[ASVS 3.4.5] Cookie Path-Attribut ungenau
Unter der gleichen Domäne laufen mehrere Applikationen, {{Applikation A unter dem Pfad /... und Applikation B unter dem Pfad /... etc.}}. {{Applikation A}} setzt das Path-Attribut des Session-Cookies auf den Wert "/", sodass der Browser das Session-Cookie bei Anfragen auf alle Applikationen mitschickt.

Das folgende Cookie ist betroffen:
```
{{PHPSESSID}}
```

Wenn das Session-Cookie nur für eine einzige Applikation bestimmt ist, kann es sein, dass es von einer anderen Applikation unter der gleichen Domäne weniger sicher gehandhabt wird oder mit Cookies anderer solcher Applikationen interferiert.

AMQP Cleartext Authentication

The remote host is running a service that allows cleartext authentication.

The remote Advanced Message Queuing Protocol (AMQP) service supports one or more authentication mechanisms that allow credentials to be sent in the clear. The data transmission may be intercepted under certain circumstances. 

If the AMQP communication is intercepted by an attacker {{in the internal network}}, then the submitted credentials are henceforth known by the attacker.

[VPN] Tunnel Modus "Split Tunneling"
Die VPN-Tunnel werden im sogenannten "Split Tunneling" Modus aufgesetzt. Hierbei wird sowohl über die VPN-Verbindung als auch direkt mit dem Internet kommuniziert.
Dadurch ist es nicht möglich sämtlichen Datenverkehr zu überwachen, was dazu führen kann, dass Benutzer auf unsichere Inhalte zugreifen. Zusätzlich ergibt sich durch die Verbindung in beide Netze eine erhöhte Angriffsfläche und kann bei Kompromittierung des Benutzergerätes zu Risiken für das Geschäftsnetz führen.

SSH Password-Based Authentication Enabled
The server configuration allows logging in using a password. This is considered insecure because the used login method is vulnerable to brute-force attacks.
An attacker with enough resources may be able to guess passwords for standard user accounts.
Thereby, all possible password combinations are tried.

[M365] Access From Any Machine and Any Network
Users can use their accounts on arbitrary machines and in arbitrary networks to log into cloud apps.

Hence, user credentials or some data might be stolen on an insecure machine.

[M365] MFA Bypass (Second Factor)
Users must enable MFA (multi-factor authentication) the next time they log in. However, the enabled factors can be deleted within an active session without access to the deleted factor.

This allows an attacker with brief access to a session and knowledge of the password to effectively bypass the second factor and set another one.

[Windows Client] Secure Boot deaktiviert
Secure Boot ist nicht aktiviert.

Secure Boot erlaubt es dem UEFI BIOS, den Bootloader vor dem Start zu überprüfen und sicherzustellen, dass er von Microsoft signiert ist.

Wenn Secure Boot deaktiviert ist, kann Schadsoftware möglicherweise den Bootprozess kompromittieren und sich dadurch vor dem Betriebssystem verbergen.

[Windows Client] Starten von externen Medien erlaubt
Das Boot-Menü lässt sich während des Startvorgangs mittels {{Funktionstaste F12}} aufrufen. Dort stehen angeschlossene USB-Sticks, SD-Karten sowie PXE als Startmöglichkeiten zur Auswahl.

Dies erlaubt es einem Angreifer, ein anderes Betriebssystem auf dem Client zu starten, um gezielte Angriffe (z. B. gegen die Festplattenverschlüsselung) durchzuführen.

>{{Bemerkung: Da Secure Boot deaktiviert ist (siehe Befund XY), können auch unsignierte Betriebssysteme gestartet werden.}}

[Windows Client] Dateien mit sensiblen Inhalten
Es wurden folgende Dateien mit sensiblen Inhalten identifiziert:
- {{Dateipfade}}
Die Existenz weiterer Dateien kann nicht ausgeschlossen werden.

Die Dateien können von Standardbenutzern gelesen werden und beinhalten unter anderem {{Passwörter im Klartext, reversible Passwörter sowie BitLocker-Wiederherstellungsschlüssel}}.

Diese Informationen können für weitere Angriffe missbraucht werden.

[Windows Client] Device und Credential Guard nicht aktiv
Erweiterte Sicherheitsmechanismen wie Device Guard und Credential Guard sind nicht aktiviert.

Diese Funktionen härten das Windows-Betriebssystem zusätzlich, indem sie verhindern, dass nicht vertrauenswürdige Software auf dem Gerät ausgeführt wird, und indem sie die Anmeldeinformationen von nicht privilegierter Software isolieren.

[Windows Client] SmartScreen Filter deaktiviert
Der Microsoft SmartScreen Filter ist {{für den Datei-Explorer}} deaktiviert.

Daher wird ein Benutzer weder davor gewarnt noch daran gehindert, potenzielle Schadsoftware herunterzuladen oder auszuführen.

[Windows Client] Internet Explorer nicht mehr unterstützt
Auf dem Client ist der Internet Explorer installiert.

Microsoft hat dessen Entwicklung eingestellt, weshalb der Browser seit dem 15. Juni 2022 auf mehreren Windows-Betriebssystemen nicht mehr unterstützt wird.

Dies führt unter anderem dazu, dass keine Sicherheitsupdates mehr verfügbar sind.

Weitere Informationen:
- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/lifecycle/faq/internet-explorer-microsoft-edge

[Windows Client] Bildschirmschoner-Timeout zu hoch
Die definierte Inaktivitätsgrenze des Clients beträgt {{3'600}} Sekunden. Entsprechend wird der Computer erst nach einer Stunde ohne Benutzerinteraktion gesperrt.

Vergisst ein Benutzer die Session zu beenden oder den Desktop explizit zu sperren, kann ein Angreifer dies ausnutzen, um sich unberechtigten Zugriff zu verschaffen.

[ASVS 6.3.2] Zufallszahlengenerator erstellt vorhersehbare UUIDs/GUIDs
Eine in der Webapplikation eingesetzte GUID-Bibliothek oder ein fehlerhafter Zufallszahlengenerator erstellen anhand einer Funktion vorhersehbare UUIDs/GUIDs.
UUIDs/GUIDs die mit schwachen Zufallszahlengeneratoren erstellt wurden können vorhersehbar sein und missbraucht werden. Ihr Einsatz wird bei Passwortrücksetzungs- oder Authentifizierungsfunktionen, z.B. eines API Bearer Tokens nicht empfohlen.

[ASVS 6.3.2] Random number generator creates predictable UUIDs/GUIDs
A GUID library used in the web application or a faulty random number generator (PRNG) create predictable UUIDs/GUIDs based on a used function.
UUIDs/GUIDs created with weak random number generators can be predictable and misused. Their use is not recommended for password reset or authentication functions, e.g. as an API bearer token.

Remote Code Execution (RCE) via File Upload
It was possible to upload executable {{.php}} files to the server.
Those files could then be accessed to execute arbitrary commands on the server. It would have been possible to copy, modify and delete sensitive data.

The server can then be used to attack other systems (external and those on the same network). Attacks on the employees of {{company name}} are possible as well.

Affected request:
- {{example request}}

Further information on the vulnerability is listed in {{chapter with further information}} in the final report.

Remote Code Execution (RCE) via Dateiupload
Es war möglich, ausführbare {{.php}} Dateien auf den Server zu laden.
Auf diese Dateien konnte dann zugegriffen werden, um beliebige Befehle auf dem Server auszuführen. Es wäre möglich gewesen, sensible Daten zu kopieren, zu ändern und zu löschen.

Der Server kann dann für Angriffe auf andere Systeme (externe und interne im selben Netzwerk) verwendet werden. Auch Angriffe auf die Mitarbeiter von {{Firmenname}} sind möglich.

Betroffene Anfrage:
- {{Beispielanfrage}}

Weitere Informationen zur Schwachstelle sind im {{Kapitel mit weiteren Informationen}} im Schlussbericht aufgeführt.

Test and Productive Environment on Same Server
The test environment is running on the same server as the productive environment.
Testing environments are usually less secure than their productive counter parts. If an attacker manages to successfully attack the test environment, there is the high chance of them being able to also ac-cess data of the productive environment.

Since new features that could introduce new security vulnerabilities or could cause a high system load (which might lead to interruptions of the service) are tested in the same test environment, this risk is in-creased even further.

Test- und Produktivumgebung auf demselben Server
Test- und Produktivumgebung auf demselben Server
Die Testumgebung läuft auf demselben Server wie die Produktivumgebung.

Testumgebungen sind in der Regel weniger sicher als ihre produktiven Gegenstücke. Wenn es einem Angreifer gelingt, die Testumgebung erfolgreich anzugreifen, ist die Wahrscheinlichkeit groß, dass er auch auf Daten der Produktivumgebung zugreifen kann.

Da neue Funktionen, die neue Schwachstellen verursachen können, in derselben Testumgebung getestet werden, erhöht das Risiko zusätzlich.

[Active Directory (AD)] Passwort in Attribut gespeichert
Es wurden Benutzerkonten identifiziert, die in einem Attribut Passwörter gespeichert haben.

Betroffene Benutzerkonten:
{{Benutzername}}

Betroffene Attribute:
{{userpassword oder unixpassword}}

Die Attribute "userPassword" oder "unixUserPassword" werden eingesetzt, um Passwörter für Verbindungen zu Unix- oder Mainframe-Systemen zu speichern. Hierdurch kann auf solchen Systemen Single Sign-On umgesetzt werden.

Die Speicherung erfolgt jedoch innerhalb eines ungesicherten Attributes, bei dem in diesem Fall die Passwörter im Klartext abgelegt sind und das von jedem authentifizierten Benutzer ausgelesen werden kann.

Ein Angreifer ist somit in der Lage, Passwörter für verbundene Systeme einfach auszulesen und diese für weitere Angriffe zu verwenden.

[Active Directory (AD)] Password Stored in Attribute
User accounts were identified that had passwords stored in an attribute.

Affected user accounts:
{{username}}

Affected attributes:
{{userpassword or unixpassword}}
The attributes "userPassword" or "unixUserPassword" are used to store passwords for connections to Unix or mainframe systems. This allows single sign-on to be implemented on such systems.

However, the storage takes place within an unsecured attribute either in plain text or mostly poorly encrypted.

An attacker is thus able to easily read passwords for connected systems.

Doppelte SPNs
Benutzerkonten der Domäne teilen sich einen Service Principal Name (SPN).

Betroffener SPN mit dem Benutzer, auf den er angewendet wird:

SPN:
-{Benutzername1}
-{Benutzername2}
Da ein SPN in der Regel für einen einzelnen Benutzer angegeben wird, kann Kerberos Anfragen für den SPN nicht authentifizieren oder wird sogar auf Net-NTLM heruntergestuft.

Die Authentifizierung durch das Net-NTLM Protokoll kann von einem Angreifer einfacher für einen Angriff verwendet werden, als die Kerberos Authentifizierung. Dies liegt zum einen an der stärkeren Verschlüsselung des Kerberos Protokolls, zum anderen an der Verifizierung durch Dritte (in diesem Fall das Key Distribution Center).

Double SPNs
User accounts of the domain share a Service Principal Name (SPN).

Affected SPN with the user to which it is applied:

SPN:
-{username1}
-{username2}
Because an SPN is usually specified for a single user, Kerberos cannot authenticate requests for the SPN or is even downgraded to Net-NTLM.

Authentication through the Net-NTLM protocol can be more easily used by an attacker for an attack than Kerberos authentication. This is partly due to the stronger encryption of the Kerberos protocol, and partly due to verification by a third party (in this case, the Key Distribution Center).

LDAP Signing
Signing is not enforced on the LDAP service.
This compromises the integrity of the protocol and allows an attacker to launch man-in-the-middle or relaying attacks on the LDAP service.

[Active Directory (AD)] Print Spooler Service / Print Server
The print spooler service is active on the domain controllers and accessible via the network.
Using the MS-RPRN RPC interface provided by the print spooler service, a domain user can force the service to authenticate to any other device. This can be abused to launch Net-NTLM relaying attacks. If the attacker already has access to a system or a user with configured unconstrained delegation, he can also obtain the TGT-Kerberos ticket of the machine account.

[Active Directory (AD)] User With Reversible Password
A user account was identified that has the user account control flag UF_ENCRYPTED_TEXT_PASSWORD_ALLOWED set. This means that the user's password is stored under reversible encryption in the Active Directory.

Affected user:
* {{User}}
Reversible passwords can be retrieved in cleartext using a DCSync attack.

[Active Directory (AD)] Benutzer mit reversiblem Passwort
Es wurde ein Benutzerkonto identifiziert, bei dem das Benutzerkontosteuerungsflag UF_ENCRYPTED_TEXT_PASSWORD_ALLOWED gesetzt ist. Dies bedeutet, dass das Kennwort des Benutzers unter umkehrbarer Verschlüsselung im Active Directory gespeichert ist.

Betroffener Benutzer:
* {{Benutzer}}
Umkehrbare Kennwörter können mit einem DCSync-Angriff im Klartext abgerufen werden.

Powershell Logging / Module & Script Block logging
According to the information read out, PowerShell commands are not logged. PowerShell "Module Logging" and "Script Block Logging" are not activated.
Malicious commands executed via PowerShell cannot be easily detected. Furthermore, no logs are available that would show which PowerShell scripts were executed.

[Active Directory (AD)] Certificate Template Misconfiguration
The following certificate template was found that allows users to control the subject and can be used for client authentication:
* {{Certificate Template}}

An attacker can set the subject to an administrator account and thus obtain a certificate representing him. This certificate can later be misused to log on to systems as the subject.

More information on abusing Active Directory Certificate Services including the here found certificate template misconfiguration (ESC1):
* https://specterops.io/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2022/06/Certified_Pre-Owned.pdf
* https://posts.specterops.io/certified-pre-owned-d95910965cd2

[Active Directory (AD)] Recycle Bin feature disabled
The "Recycle Bin" functionality of the Active Directory is deactivated.
If Active Directory objects are deleted, they can no longer be easily restored. Objects that were accidentally or specifically deleted by an attacker must be restored from external backups. Furthermore, fewer traces are available for forensic investigations.

[Active Directory (AD)] Unknown Account in Delegation
A delegation has been identified where the account cannot be translated to a NT account. This means that the delegation is either from another domain or that the account has been deleted.

Affected delegation:
* {{Delegation}}
This increases the attack surface.

[Active Directory (AD)] Unbekanntes Konto in Delegierung
Es wurde eine Delegierung identifiziert, bei welcher der Security Identifier (SID)  nicht in ein NT-Konto übersetzt werden kann.

Betroffene Delegierung:
* {{Delegierung}}

Dies bedeutet, dass die Delegierung entweder aus einer anderen Domäne stammt oder dass das Konto gelöscht wurde. Dadurch wird die Angriffsfläche vergrössert.

[Active Directory (AD)] LLMNR Discovery GPO / group policy
No group policy has been identified that disables the Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) protocol. This protocol is used as a name resolution substitute for networks in which no DNS server is active or accessible.
If a name resolution is started via LLMNR, every device in the current network is automatically trusted. This allows an attacker who is on the same network to respond to such requests to perform a man-in-the-middle attack.

[Active Directory (AD)] Account with Unconstrained Delegation Rights
There are accounts with unrestricted delegation rights.

Affected  accounts:
* {{Account}}
This allows the account to impersonate all accounts that log on to it. If the account is compromised, its rights can be used for any actions when an administrator logs in.

[API] X-Frame-Options
The X-Frame-Options HTTP header is not set. Like the CSP header, the X-Frame-Options header is a hardening measure that protects the API against client-side attacks.

Without the X-Frame-Options header, the API is potentially vulnerable to drag-and-drop clickjacking attacks, in which the attacker attempts to get the user to perform a drag-and-drop action using an invisible inline frame that could give the attacker access to the API response.

More information:
- https://www.w3.org/Security/wiki/Clickjacking_Threats#Drag_and_drop_attacks

[mobile] App Transport Security (ATS) Exceptions
The app defines multiple App Transport Security (ATS) exceptions, which allow for unencrypted communications.

The "NSExceptionAllowsInsecureHTTPLoads" key defined in the "NSExceptionDomains" dictionary is used to explicitly allow an app to communicate with a domain over an insecure HTTP connection, even if App Transport Security (ATS) is enabled.



Allowing insecure HTTP connections makes the app and its users vulnerable to a range of attacks such as man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks. Attackers can intercept the communication between the app and the server, steal sensitive data or inject malicious code, which can compromise the security of the app and its users.

In addition, allowing insecure HTTP connections can also compromise the compliance of the application with regulatory standards such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) or the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI-DSS), which require the use of secure HTTPS connections.

The vulnerabilities could, for instance, allow attackers to execute arbitrary code (remote code execution) or read sensitive information processed by the network stack.

[M365] Microsoft Defender 365 Standardeinstellungen

[M365] Flow für alle Nutzer zugänglich (früher Power Automate)
Jeder Microsoft 365 Nutzer kann "Flow" (früher Power Automate) auf dem eignen Gerät unter folgender URL nutzen:
* https://flow.microsoft.com

Es ist damit möglich Arbeitsabläufe zu kreieren die automatisch daten (z.B. SharePoint Ordner) an einen externen Service senden. Dies kann unter anderem Dropbox, ein eigener FTP oder SSH-Server sein.
Damit ist es auch möglich Daten von aussen in den Tennant zu laden.
Dadurch ist Daten-Exfiltration sowie Einschleusen von unbekannten Daten möglich.

[M365] Nutzer können M365 Applikation nachladen
Die Einstellungen erlauben spezifisch für M365 entwickelte Applikationen genutzt werden dürfen. Dies erlaubt es Anwen-dern, Applikationen ohne formale Prüfung nachzuladen und im Kontext von M365 auszuführen. 
Das Risiko dabei ist, dass ein Angreifer eine Schadsoftware einschleusen und damit zum Beispiel Nutzerdaten oder andere Daten stehlen kann.

[M365] Exchange Konfiguration der Filterung ausgehender Spam
Die Konfiguration bezüglich ausgehenden Spam ist nicht gesetzt. 
Dadurch könnte ein Angreifer ungehindert Spam versenden, sobald er einen Nutzer kompromittiert hat. Die eigene Domäne könnte daher auf eine liste kommen als Spamversender.

[M365] Teams Gäste Einstellungen
Es ist erlaubt, dass externe als Gäste, Teams vollumfänglich nutzen dürfen. Dabei sind die Grundeinstellungen nicht restriktiv genug. Es ist auch möglich, in Teams, Daten auf externen Cloud Anbie-tern (Dropbox, Google Drive, etc.) zu speichern.

Nutzer exponieren somit Daten und könnten per M365 Apps kompromittiert werden.

[M365] Verhinderung von Datenverlust nicht aktiviert (DLP)
Es gibt keine Mechanismen der eingesetzt wird zur Verhinderung von Datenverlust. Dadurch können Nutzer ungewollt Daten jemandem übermitteln, der diese nicht haben sollte.
Ein Risiko entsteht, dass Daten Dritten zugänglich gemacht werden. Es ist möglich, dass dadurch Datenschutzgesetze verletzt werden.

[M365] Exchange Freigabe von Kalenderdetails nicht eingeschränkt
Externe Nutzer können Kalenderdetails einsehen. Dadurch werden die Einträge der Nutzer exponiert.
Daten und Informationen können durch den uneingeschränkten Zugriff auf Kalenderdetails abfliessen.

[Azure] [M365] Externe Zugriffsrechte in Azure Active Directory Vergeben (Gastzugriff)
Es gibt einige externe Konten, die sich über nicht kontrollierte Identitätsverwalter authentifizieren. 

Gefundene Accounts:
{{TODO}}

Dadurch können externe Personen, auf Ressourcen die in Teams, sowie in Teams transferierte Daten in SharePoint, zugreifen. Dies erhöht die Angriffsfläche.

[M365] Genutzte Lizenzen sind Sicherheitslimitierend
Die genutzten Lizenzen haben verschie-dene Einschränkungen bezüglich Sicherheitsfunktionen. Microsoft bietet unter anderem erst ab Lizenzen des Enterprise Modells (E5) den Zugriffsschutz der Daten gegenüber Microsoft (Customer Lockbox, Azure Information Protection). 
Diverse Sicherheitseinstellungen können mit dem verwendeten Lizenzmodell nicht verwendet werden und dies erhöht das Risiko eines erfolgreichen Angriffs gegen M365. Es ist unter dem jetzigen Modell nicht möglich den Zugriff von Microsoft auf die Daten in M356 zu verhindern.

Apache Commens Text CVE-2022-42889 (Text4Shell)
The target system runs a vulnerable version of Apache Commons Text.

Affected parameters:
- {{ param }}

Example request:
```
POST /example HTTP/1.1
Host: foo
```

This is vulnerability indicates, that there is no working input validation present (see Risk XY) 

{{ Note: See chapter XY for more information on how this vulnerability }}

By successfully exploiting this vulnerability, an attacker my execute arbitrary code on the vulnerable system.

For more information, see:
-	CVE-2022-42889
-	https://security.apache.org/blog/cve-2022-42889/

[ASVS 5.2.4] Usage of eval() for Dynamic Code Execution
The application uses the eval() function to dynamically execute JavaScript code.

Usage of the eval() function is unsafe because it can expose the application to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks, where an adversary injects JavaScript code into parameters supplied to the eval() function. Successful XSS allows an adversary to run JavaScript code in the browser of an active user.

[Mail] SPF with "softfail" mechanism
The current SPF configuration uses the completion criterion "~all", which means "softfail". This allows emails from sources other than the explicitly listed mechanisms (MX records, IP addresses, etc.) to not be actively rejected, but to be flagged as potentially suspicious or subject the message to closer scrutiny than normal. 

Current SPF:
```
{{ v=spf1 ... }}
```

This could be exploited by attackers to send spoofed emails, as the recipient's email server may decide to deliver the email anyway, even though it does not comply with the SPF policy.

[Mail] No action defined in DMARC for spoofed emails
The current Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) configuration uses "p=none", which means that no specific action is set for emails that cannot be confirmed with Sender Policy Framework (SPF) or DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM). This configuration does not provide clear instructions on how to deal with spoofed emails. 

Current DMARC policy:
```
{{ v=DMARC1; p=none; rua=mailto:...; ruf=mailto:d...; }}
```

This could be exploited by attackers to send spoofed emails, as the recipient's email server may decide to deliver the email anyway, even though it does not comply with the SPF policy or fails the DKIM verification.

GraphQL Introspection Enabled
The GraphQL endpoint has introspection enabled. This allows attackers to query for information about the underlying schema. This includes data like types, fields, queries, mutations, or field-level descriptions.

Example request:
{{ Request }}

Response:
{{ Response }}

Such information may help an attacker to discover vulnerabilities in the system.

Same Certificate for Test and Production
The system uses a certificate that is issued for both the test and
production systems. The following domains are included in the
certificate:
- domain1
If an adversary manages to compromise the private key of this
certificate, they will be able to masquerade as systems of the listed
domains. This simplifies man-in-the-middle attacks considerably.
This risk is increased because the same certificate is used for test
and production systems. Test systems are usually less protected
than the production system.

[Advanced Mail Test] PGP Email Encryption Bypasses the File Extension Filter
Emails encrypted with PGP arrive in a user's mailbox, regardless
of the mail content.

An attacker can take advantage of this situation by adding any
dangerous attachments to the mail. Through a phishing attack, an
attacker can trick an {{ XYZ }} employee into decrypting the encrypted email and opening the dangerous attachments.

[Active Directory (AD)] Keine Tier-Isolierung für Administratoren durch GPO
Administratorkonten werden nicht durch eine Gruppenrichtlinie in Tiers isoliert.

Standardmäßig können Administratoren eine Verbindung zu einer kompromittierten Workstation herstellen, wo ein Angreifer den Diebstahl von Anmeldeinformationen oder die Kerberos-Delegation für das betroffene Konto durchführen kann.



Es fehlt somit eine empfohlene Abhärtungsmaßnahme.

> Anmerkung: Es ist möglich, dass die erwartete GPO aufgrund von ACL-Prüfungen verborgen ist und die Tier-Isolierung für Administratorkonten aktiviert ist.

[Active Directory (AD)] ADCS Certificates With Enrollment Rights for Authenticated Users
On the Active Directory Certificate Services (ADCS) server {{Certificate Authority Name}}, the following certificate templates allow any authenticated user to enroll in them:
* {{Certificate Template Name}}

Furthermore, the manager approval is disabled, and no authorized signatures are required.

Usually, the subject of a certificate is generated automatically by the certification authority.

By allowing editing before its issuance, a malicious user can set the subject to an administrator account, and thus get a certificate impersonating an administrator.

Using this, an attacker can become the domain administrator relatively quickly.

[Active Directory (AD)] ADCS Certificates With Enrollment Rights for Domain Computers
On the Active Directory Certificate Services (ADCS) server {{Certificate Authority Name}}, the following certificate templates allow any domain computer to enroll in them:
* {{Certificate Template Name}}

Furthermore, the manager approval is disabled, and no authorized signatures are required.
Usually, the subject of a certificate is generated automatically by the certification authority.

By allowing editing before its issuance, a malicious user can set the subject to an administrator account, and thus get a certificate impersonating an administrator.

Using this, an attacker can become the domain administrator relatively quickly.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-Kerberoasting] Administrative User Vulnerable to Kerberoasting
A domain administrator account is assigned with a Service Principal Name (SPN).

Affected account:
{{username}}
This makes it vulnerable to so-called Kerberoasting. 

If a weak password is set on a service account (with a set Service Principal Name), attackers may be able to use the attack technique Kerberoasting to guess the password by brute force or wordlists – and all this offline without being logged on to the domain any longer. 

If the domain administrator password is successfully cracked, the entire forest is compromised.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DelegationDCt2a4d] User Account has Constrained Delegation on Domain Controller
A user account exists, which has constrained delegation rights on a domain controller with protocol transition.

Affected user account:
{{username}}

Affected domain controller:
{{computername$}}

An attacker who has compromised the affected user account, can impersonate any user (including domain admins) on the domain controller and run commands on behalf of them. Therefore, a domain takeover is possible.

[Active Directory (AD)] ADCS Certificate Authority With Enrollment Rights for Authenticated Users
The following Active Directory Certificate Services (ADCS) servers allow any authenticated user to enroll in them:
* {{Certificate Authority Name}}
* {{Certificate Authority Name}}

Furthermore, enrollees can specify the subject alternative name (SAN), and the field “Request Disposition” is set to “Issue”.

By allowing editing before its issuance, a malicious user can set the subject to an administrator account, and thus get a certificate impersonating an administrator.

Using this, an attacker can become the domain administrator relatively quickly.

> Note: This escalation path has been patched by Microsoft in May 2022. However, it still works if two registry keys are set on the affected domain controller to the following values:
> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\Schannel CertificateMappingMethods containing the UPN bit (0x4)
> HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Kdc StrongCertificateBindingEnforcement set to 0
> As these registry keys cannot be checked with the given privileges, it is recommended to verify the settings by a privileged user.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-PwdGPO] Stored Credentials in Group Policy Objects
Credentials are stored in Group Policy Objects (GPO).

These are encrypted with a static AES256 key published on the following Microsoft website:
* http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/2c15cbf0-f086-4c74-8b70-1f2fa45dd4be.aspx

An attacker can decrypt the password and obtain further access using the credentials.

Affected Group Policy:
```
{{gpo name}}
```

Identified credentials:
```
{{username}}
```

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-DCLdapSign] Missing LDAP Signing
The domain controllers do not currently use LDAP signing.

The LDAP signature feature ensures the integrity of network communication between the computer and the domain controller.

LDAP communication is not signed, which compromises the integrity of the protocol.

Attackers aim to intercept the communication at the network layer and modify the network dialog to grant themselves admin privileges. 

Without LDAP signing, Net-NTLM relaying attacks, such as those triggered by patchable vulnerabilities like PetitPotam, can be directed against domain controllers and lead to domain admin privileges.

Affected domain controllers:
* {{domain controller$}}
* {{domain controller$}}

[Active Directory (AD)] Administrative Accounts With Old Passwords
Various highly privileged Active Directory accounts have not changed their password for more than three years. 

The following accounts were identified:
* {{username}}
* {{username}}

People who have had access to the password during these years can still perform any actions under this account. 

Some of the passwords might already be compromised as well.

[Azure] No Conditional Access Policy for Administrative Resources ("Microsoft Azure Management")
No Conditional Access policy restricting access to the "Microsoft Azure Management" application has been configured.

As a result, some users with high privileges, such as owner and write permissions on Azure resources {{ , that are not assigned a role covered by the existing Conditional Access policies for administrative access, do not require MFA in some cases (e.g., when signing in from a trusted location) }} .

[Azure] Conditional Access Policies Missing Administrative Roles
The Conditional Access policies for administrative access do not include all administrative directory groups.

Both policies do not include the {{ "Authentication Administrator" and "Authentication Policy Administrator" }} roles for example.

Affected Conditional Access policies:
- {{ BLOCK - Admins from non jumphost }}
- {{ REQUIRE MFA - All admins }}

This can result in intended conditions not being applied to all administrative accounts. Thus, for example, {{ MFA could not be required for some administrative users }} .

[Azure] Administrative Accounts in On-Premises Active Directory
The highly privileged accounts used for administrative tasks in Azure are members of the on-premises domain and synced to Azure AD.

{{ This is due the current identity management process and because they are also used to authenticate on the jumphost for Azure administration. }}

This significantly increases the attack surface. If such an on-premises account is compromised, it can lead to compromise of Azure resources as well.

[Azure] PIM: Approval for Eligible Role Activation Not Required
Eligible users can activate administrative Azure AD roles (e.g., Global Administrator) and Azure resource roles (e.g., Owner) without approval by an additional administrator.

This poses the risk that malicious activations of administrative roles are not detected in time or not detected at all.

[Azure] Inconsistent Conditional Access Policies
The Conditional Access policies for administrative access have a discrepancy {{ in the number of included groups }} .

Even though the policies should cover all administrative roles, one policy includes {{ 55 }} roles whereas the other policy only includes {{ 45 }} roles.

Affected Conditional Access policies:
- {{ BLOCK - Admins from non jumphost }}
- {{ REQUIRE MFA - All admins }}

Inconsistent policies can result in intended conditions not being applied to all administrative accounts. Thus, for example, {{ MFA could not be required for some administrative users }} .

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: S-OldNtlm] LM/NTLMv1 Allowed
No group policy was found that disables old network authentication protocols.

Therefore, the LAN Manager authentication level is set by default to send LM/NTLMv1 responses. 

These protocols are using weak hashing algorithms. Due to its flawed design, hashes retrieved from the network authentication protocol can be converted back to the plaintext password or a reusable password hash in seconds.

An attacker may easily crack these hashes and get user credentials.

More information:
*  https://crack.sh/netntlm/

[Active Directory (AD)] Authenticated Users Have Various Privileges on Domain Objects
The group Authenticated Users has the following privileges on the following domain objects:
```
{{GenericWrite 	 domain object
WriteOwner 	 domain object
WriteDacl 	 domain object
etc.}}
```


This allows any user to compromise the domain objects and use it for lateral movement attempts.

[Azure] Self-Service Group Management
All users are allowed to create new security groups and add members to these groups.

Affected setting:
- Users can create security groups: Yes

Furthermore, the following settings enable self-service group management:
- Owners can manage group membership requests: Yes
- Restrict user ability to access groups features in the Access Pane: No

This violates the principle of least privilege and therefore allows potential abuse by attackers. Additionally, it adds complexity to access control management and increases the risk of data exposure and leakage.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-NoServicePolicy] Password Requirements for Service Accounts Too Low
Service accounts are subject to the general password policy.

If a weak password is set on a service account, attackers may be able to use the attack technique "Kerberoasting" (for service accounts with a set service principal name) to guess the password by brute force or wordlists - and all this offline without being logged on to the domain. 

This increases the attack surface of the Active Directory environment.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-HardenedPaths] Missing Hardening for UNC Paths
The following values are missing hardening measures:
```
\\{{domain name}}\sysvol
\\{{domain name}}\netlogon
```

For these values, mutual authentication, integrity mode and privacy mode are disabled.

Attackers with SYSTEM privileges can inject malicious group policies during a group policy update.

[Active Directory (AD)] Several Outdated Operating Systems
A large number of domain-joined devices use an obsolete operating system that is no longer supported.

These operating systems thus also no longer receive security updates. 

This makes them an obvious target for an attacker.

More information can be found in {{chapter}}.

> Note: The information about the operating system version in use was extracted from the metadata of the computer accounts in the Active Directory. In scope of this project, it could not be verified whether the obsolete equipment is still in operation. However, the computer accounts are still present in the domain, enabled, and have logged on within the last 90 days. Additionally, there may be other obsolete devices that were not identified using this search metric.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DNSAdmin] DNS Admins Group Not Empty
There are accounts in the "DNS Admins" group.

Members in the "DNS Admins" group:
* {{username}}
* {{username}}

Administrators of the DNS service have the possibility to perform a DLL injection for the DNS service. However, this service is hosted in the domain controller most of the time and is running as SYSTEM. That means that members of the “DNS Admins” group are potentially domain admins.

An attacker who compromises one of these accounts can therefore take over the domain.

> Note: Although a privilege escalation path from DNS Admins to SYSTEM rights on the domain controller using DLL injection has been patched, it is still recommended to avoid such given privileges.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-OperatorsEmpty] Operator Groups Not Empty
There are accounts in the “Account Operators” and “Server Operators” group.

Members in the "Account Operators" group:
* {{username}}

Members in the "Server Operators" group:
* {{username}}

Users within these groups are having administrative rights, which an attacker can abuse.

[Active Directory (AD)] Computer Accounts Without Password Enforcement
The following computer accounts can be set up without a password because the "PASSWD_NOTREQD" flag is set in the "useraccountcontrol".

This poses a security risk, as the computer account is potentially not protected with a password.

A list of affected computers can be found in {{chapter}}.

> Note: Just because an account can have an empty password does not mean that it will. Nevertheless, the setting should be adjusted.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-AuditDC] No Extended Audit Policy on Domain Controller
The audit policy on the domain controller does not capture key events.

To detect and mitigate attacks, the right events must be collected. The audit policy is a compromise between too many events to collect, and too few.

More information on missing configuration is available in {{chapter}}.

No Tier Isolation for Administrators Enforced by GPO
Administrator accounts are not isolated in tiers by a group policy.

By default, administrators are allowed to connect to a compromised workstation, where an attacker can carry out credential theft or Kerberos delegation for the affected account.

Therefore, a recommended hardening measure is missing.

> Note: It is possible that the expected GPO is hidden due to ACL checks, and the tier isolation for administrator accounts is enabled.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-DCRefuseComputerPwdChange] Changing of Computer Account Passwords Denied by GPO
A Group Policy Object (GPO) exists, which denies the change of the password for computer accounts every 30 days.

Group Policy Object:
```
{{gpo name}}
```

When an attacker compromises a computer account without regular password changes, they gain long term access to the domain and can use it as a persistence mechanism.

[Active Directory (AD)] User Accounts Without Password Change Possibility
Various Active Directory accounts have the option to change the account password disabled. 

A list of affected accounts can be found in {{chapter}}.

This forces a user to use the given password permanently, which increases the likelihood that the account will be compromised.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-SHA1RootCert] Certificate Weakly Signed
The following certificate is signed with a relatively weak key length (SHA1).
* {{certificate name}}

Currently, this combination of algorithm and key length is still considered secure, but the certificate has a validity of over 10 years and will no longer be recommended by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) after 2030.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DCOwner] Domain Accounts Own Domain Controllers
Domain accounts which are the owner of one or more domain controllers exist in the domain.

Domain account:
* {{username}}

Owned domain controller:

An attacker who compromises one of the affected domain accounts has access to domain controllers. A domain takeover is therefore possible.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: S-KerberosArmoringDC & S-KerberosArmoring] No Kerberos Armoring Enabled
Kerberos Armoring is not enabled in the domain for neither domain controllers, nor for clients.

Without Kerberos Armoring, an additional protection layer is missing, which prevents pre-authentication attacks.

> Note: Kerberos Armoring is only available for at least a domain functional level Windows Server 2012 and at least Windows 8 workstations. If Kerberos Armoring is requested for other operating systems (e.g., Windows 7 or Linux), the Kerberos authentication protocol may refuse to work.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: T-SIDFiltering] Trust Without SID Filtering
The trust relationship with "{{trust name}}" is configured without SID filtering.

This allows an attacker who has gained domain administrator privileges on one of the two domains to achieve elevated privileges on the respective other domain, even if in another forest, for example by manipulating the SID history.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DelegationLoginScript] Logon Script Writable by Everyone
A file that is executed upon logon is writeable by any user.

The group policy "{{group policy name}}" is applied to the organizational unit "{{ou name}}" in the domain. 
It refers to a file “{{logon script name}}”, which is executed at logon.

Affected file path:
```
{{path to logon script}}
```

Since the file, which is executed as a logon script, is writable by the group "Domain Users", all users can extend their rights.

[Active Directory (AD)] ADCS Web Enrollment Endpoint Potentially Vulnerable
On the Active Directory Certificate Services (ADCS) server, the following Web Enrollment endpoint is enabled:
* {{https://web-enrollment-endpoint}}

By default, Microsoft does not enable the Extended Protection for Authentication (EPA) security mechanism on this endpoint, which would prevent Net-NTLM relaying. 

If the default setting has not been changed, the endpoint is thus vulnerable to Net-NTLM relaying, which allows an attacker to become the domain administrator relatively quickly.

> Note: As there are no attack tools being run in this audit part that could clearly detect enabled or disabled EPA, this can be a false positive and is something you should have your staff check who have direct access to the server.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-LoginDCEveryone] Interactive Logon on Domain Controllers for Regular Users
In the default Domain Controllers policy, the SeInteractivelogonRight privilege is granted to the Domain Users group. 

This allows regular domain users to log in locally or semi-locally using remote management software such as VNC.

An attacker could therefore gain elevated privileges through local privilege escalation on the local domain controller.

This can lead to a takeover of the domain.

[Active Directory (AD)] Duplicate SPNs
Users in the domain share a Service Principal Name (SPN). 


Because an SPN is typically specified for a single user, Kerberos cannot authenticate requests for the SPN, or will even downgrade to Net-NTLM.

Affected SPN with the user its applied to:

{{service principal name}}:
* {{username}}
* {{username}}

[Active Directory (AD)] Outdated Forest Functional Level
The Forest Functional Level is currently based on {{Windows Server 2008 R2}}.

This does not directly represent a safety risk, but it does not correspond to the current standard.

[Active Directory (AD)] LAPS Computer Joiner Can Read Their Local Administrator Password
When a computer is added to the domain, the owner of the computer object is the user who joined the computer.

When the Local Administrator Password Solution (LAPS) is installed, the local admin account has its password stored in a special attribute named ms-mcs-AdmPwd. Its access is restricted.

Because the user who created it is the owner of the underlying object, they can retrieve the LAPS attribute and get the local admin password.

Affected computer accounts:
* {{computername$}}

Therefore, a privilege escalation from the computer joiner to other users using the machine is possible.

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Generic or Non-Admin Accounts with Administrative Privileges
The following generic account has Helpdesk Administrator privileges and is therefore a shadow administrator account:
* {{ AFFECTED ACCOUNTS }}

A Helpdesk Administrator can reset passwords for non-administrators and other Helpdesk Administrators.

A shared account reduces the traceability of actions performed by individual users.  This can lead to problems in assigning responsibility in case of misuse of a system.

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Service Principals with Administrative Privileges
The following service principals are assigned privileged roles in Microsoft Entra ID:
*{{ Affected Account (ID-ID...) }} is an {{ Administrator role, e.g. Exchange Administrator/ User Administrator }}

{{ CHECK APPLICABILITY OF ADMINISTRATOR ROLES AND DESCRIPTIONS }} An Exchange Administrator can an manage all aspects of the Exchange product. A User Administrator can manage all aspects of users and groups, including resetting passwords for limited admins.

Service principals are often overlooked when it comes to enforcing the principle of least privilege. However, they present an additional attack surface as they grant a lot of permissions to applications that could be easily compromised. Additionally, as there is no way to require service principals to activate into privileged roles, they present a potential security risk.

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: External Identities with Administrative Privileges
The following external organizations have been granted Delegated Administration Privileges (DAP):
*{{ affected organization }} for the roles {{ Affected roles, e.g. Global Admin, Helpdesk Admin }}

Delegated admin partners are Microsoft partners that have been authorized to administer Microsoft services in a tenant using Delegated Administration Privileges (DAP).

After accepting a DAP agreement, a partner can assign the Global Admin role for the organization to their employees. The Global Admin role gives the partner's employees access to employees' personal data and other sensitive information. 

It also gives them permission to take tenant-wide actions, such as:
*Changing user passwords
*Adding users with email accounts
*Adding and managing web domains associated with your organization

When DAP is enabled, the organization has no control over the number of Global Admins their partner can add. This opens the Microsoft Entra ID and connected Azure subscriptions to compromise if the partner organization is compromised.

More information:
*https://portal.azure.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_IAM/ActiveDirectoryMenuBlade/~/PartnerRelationships

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Dangerous Application API Permissions
Some applications respectively their service principals have highly critical application API permissions inside the Microsoft Entra ID tenant.

Affected application and permissions:
*{{ Affected Service Application }} with permissions {{ Affected permissions, e.g. Directory.ReadWrite.All, Exchange.ManageAsApp, User.ReadWrite.All }}


{{ CHECK APPLICABILITY OF PERMISSIONS }} For example, the permission Directory.ReadWrite.All allows the application to read and write data in the organization's directory, such as users, and groups and the permission Application.ReadWrite.All to create, and manage (read, update, update application secrets and delete) applications and service principals without a signed-in user. Additionally, more applications respective service principals have critical permissions on a lower level, for example to read all files.

If such an application is compromised, this would lead to the compromise of the entire Microsoft Entra ID and all connected Azure subscriptions.

The Domain Functional Level is currently based on {{Windows Server 2008 R2}}.

[Active Directory (AD)] Domain Controller Part of Pre-Windows 2000 Group
The "{{domain controller name$}}" domain controller is a member of the "Pre-Windows 200 Compatible Access" group.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: S-DC-NotUpdated] Missing Domain Controller Patches
The domain controller "{{domain controller name$}}" was last restarted on {{yyyy-mm-dd}}. 

This means that it can be assumed that no updates have been installed since then that require a restart.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: S-DC-2008] Unsupported Windows Installation on Domain Controller
{{Windows Server 2008 R2}} is running on the domain controller {{domain controller name$}}.

This operating system is no longer supported by Microsoft. This means not only that there will be no new security patches but also that Microsoft is unlikely to investigate or acknowledge reports of vulnerabilities for this operating system.

Unless Extended Security Updates (ESU) are bought, which would ensure updates until January 2023, this system is no longer supported:
* https://docs.microsoft.com/en-US/lifecycle/faq/extended-security-updates

[Active Directory (AD)] Authenticated Users are Group Members of Print Operators
The group “Authenticated Users” is a group member of the high privileged Print Operators group.

This right enables authenticated users to manage, create, share, and delete printers connected to domain controllers in the domain. They can also manage Active Directory printer objects in the domain. 

Furthermore, they can log on locally to domain controllers in the domain.
Local logon usually requires physical interaction. But VNC or remote server management software is one way to perform local logon remotely. 

Additionally, print operators can load kernel drivers so they can bring their own vulnerability to the system to gain administrative privileges once logged in.

This can lead to a takeover of the domain.

[Active Directory (AD)] DownLevel Trust
Following trust has been identified as DownLevel Trust:
```
{{trust name}}
```

A DownLevel Trust is compatible with Windows NT 4.0, which only supports NTLMv1 for authentication.

An attacker is able to break intercepted NTLMv1 hashes comparatively easily, gaining access to credentials.

[Active Directory (AD)] Use of Nested Groups
Groups exist within the domain, which in turn are members of other groups.

Such nested groups pose a risk because they can unintentionally extend the privileges of groups and their members.

It is also difficult to keep track of the privileges of individual accounts.

Further information can be found in {{chapter}}.

[Active Directory (AD)] ADCS Unpublished Certificate Template is Vulnerable
On the Active Directory Certificate (ADCS) server, the following certificate template is classified as vulnerable:
```
{{certificate template name}}
```
Depending on the vulnerability, the publication makes it comparatively easy for an attacker to extend his privileges to the domain administrator.

> Note: Since the affected template has not been published, it cannot be determined in detail if the template is vulnerable. Furthermore, the vulnerability cannot be exploited until the template is published. For this reason, the finding  is purely informal.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-Kerberoasting] Administrativer Benutzer anfällig für Kerberoasting
Einem hoch privilegiertem Benutzerkonto wird ein Dienstprinzipalnamen (Service Principal Name, SPN) zugewiesen.

Betroffenes Konto:
{{Benutzername}}

Dies macht es anfällig für das sogenannte Kerberoasting.

Wenn für ein Dienstkonto (mit einem festgelegten Dienstprinzipalnamen) ein schwaches Passwort festgelegt wird, können Angreifer die Angriffstechnik Kerberoasting verwenden, um das Kennwort durch Brute-Force oder Wortlisten zu erraten - und das alles offline, ohne an der Domäne angemeldet zu sein.

Wird das Passwort des Domänenadministrators erfolgreich erraten, ist der gesamte Forest kompromittiert.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DelegationDCt2a4d] Benutzerkonto hat eingeschränkte Delegation auf Domänencontroller
Es existiert ein Benutzerkonto, das eingeschränkte Delegationsrechte (Constrained Delegation) auf einem Domänencontroller mit Protokoll-Transition hat.

Betroffenes Benutzerkonto
{{Benutzername}}

Betroffener Domänencontroller
{{Computername$}}
Ein Angreifer, der das betroffene Benutzerkonto kompromittiert hat, kann sich als ein beliebiger Benutzer (einschließlich Domänenadministratoren) auf dem Domänencontroller ausgeben und Befehle in dessen Namen ausführen. Daher ist eine Domänenübernahme möglich.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-PwdGPO] Gespeicherte Anmeldeinformationen in Gruppenrichtlinienobjekten
Die Anmeldeinformationen werden in Gruppenrichtlinienobjekten (GPO) gespeichert.

Diese werden mit einem statischen AES256-Schlüssel verschlüsselt, der auf der folgenden Microsoft-Website veröffentlicht wird:
* http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/2c15cbf0-f086-4c74-8b70-1f2fa45dd4be.aspx

Ein Angreifer kann das Passwort entschlüsseln und mit den Anmeldedaten weiteren Zugriff erhalten.

Betroffene Gruppenrichtlinie:
{{gpo name}}

Identifizierte Anmeldeinformationen:
{{Benutzername}}

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-DCLdapSign] Fehlende LDAP-Signierung
Die Domänencontroller verwenden derzeit keine LDAP-Signatur.

Die LDAP-Signaturfunktion gewährleistet die Integrität der Netzwerkkommunikation zwischen dem Computer und dem Domänencontroller.

Die LDAP-Kommunikation ist nicht signiert, was die Integrität des Protokolls beeinträchtigt.
Angreifer zielen darauf ab, die Kommunikation auf der Netzwerkebene abzufangen und den Netzwerkdialog zu ändern, um sich selbst Admin-Rechte zu verschaffen.

Ohne LDAP-Signierung können Net-NTLM-Relaying-Angriffe, wie sie durch patchbare Schwachstellen wie PetitPotam ausgelöst werden, gegen Domänencontroller gerichtet werden und zu Domänenadministratorrechten führen.

Betroffene Domänencontroller:
* {{Domänencontroller$}}
* {{Domänencontroller$}}

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: S-OldNtlm] LM/NTLMv1 erlaubt
Es existiert keine Gruppenrichtlinie zur Deaktivierung alter Netzwerkauthentifizierungsprotokolle.

Dies bedeutet, dass standardmässig die Authentifizierung mittels LM, NTLMv1 und NTLMv2 unterstützt wird.

Die Protokolle LM und NTMLv1 verwenden schwache Hash-Algorithmen. Ein Angreifer kann solche Hashes leicht brechen und an die Anmeldedaten des Benutzers gelangen.

Weitere Informationen:
* https://crack.sh/netntlm

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-NoServicePolicy] Passwortanforderungen für Servicekonten zu niedrig
Für Servicekonten gilt die allgemeine Passwortrichtlinie.

Wenn für ein Servicekonto ein schwaches Passwort festgelegt ist, können Angreifer die Angriffstechnik "Kerberoasting" (für Servicekonten mit einem festgelegten Dienstprinzipalnamen - SPN) verwenden, um das Kennwort durch Brute Force oder Wortlisten zu erraten - und das alles offline, ohne an der Domäne angemeldet zu sein.

Dies vergrößert die Angriffsfläche der Active Directory-Umgebung.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-HardenedPaths] Fehlende Härtung für UNC-Pfade
Für die folgenden Pfade fehlen Härtungsmaßnahmen:
```
\\{{Domänenname}}\sysvol
\\{{Domänenname}}netlogon
```

Für diese Werte sind die gegenseitige Authentifizierung, der Integritätsmodus und der Privacy-Modus deaktiviert.

Angreifer mit SYSTEM-Rechten können während eines Gruppenrichtlinien-Updates bösartige Gruppenrichtlinien einschleusen.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DNSAdmin] DNS-Admins-Gruppe nicht leer
Es gibt Konten in der Gruppe "DNS-Admins".

Mitglieder in der Gruppe "DNS-Admins":
* {{Benutzername}}
* {{Benutzername}}

Administratoren des DNS-Dienstes haben die Möglichkeit, eine DLL-Injektion für den DNS-Dienst durchzuführen. Dieser Dienst wird jedoch die meiste Zeit auf dem Domänencontroller gehostet und als SYSTEM ausgeführt. Das bedeutet, dass Mitglieder der Gruppe "DNS Admins" potenziell Domänenadmins sind.

Ein Angreifer, der eines dieser Konten kompromittiert, kann daher die Domäne übernehmen.

> Hinweis: Obwohl ein Pfad zur Erhöhung der Privilegien von DNS-Admins auf SYSTEM-Rechte auf dem Domänencontroller mithilfe von DLL-Injection gepatcht wurde, wird immer noch empfohlen, solche gegebenen Privilegien zu vermeiden.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-OperatorsEmpty] Operator Gruppe nicht leer
Es gibt Konten in den Gruppen "Account Operators" und "Server Operators".

Mitglieder in der Gruppe "Account Operators":
* {{Benutzername}}

Mitglieder in der Gruppe "Server Operators":

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-AuditDC] Keine erweiterte Audit-Richtlinie auf dem Domänencontroller
Die Audit-Richtlinie auf dem Domänencontroller erfasst keine Schlüsselereignisse.

Um Angriffe zu erkennen und abzuschwächen, müssen die richtigen Ereignisse gesammelt werden. Die Audit-Richtlinie ist ein Kompromiss zwischen zu vielen und zu wenigen zu sammelnden Ereignissen.

Weitere Informationen zur fehlenden Konfiguration finden Sie in {{Kapitel}}.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-DCRefuseComputerPwdChange] Änderung der Passwörter von Computerkonten durch GPO verweigert
Es existiert ein Gruppenrichtlinienobjekt (GPO), das die Änderung des Kennworts für Computerkonten alle 30 Tage verbietet.

Gruppenrichtlinien-Objekt:


Wenn ein Angreifer ein Computerkonto kompromittiert, welches das Passwort nicht regelmäßig ändert, erhält er langfristigen Zugriff auf die Domäne und kann es als Persistenzmechanismus nutzen.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: A-SHA1RootCert] Schwach signiertes Zertifikat
Das folgende Zertifikat ist mit einer relativ schwachen Schlüssellänge (SHA1) signiert:
```
{{Zertifikatname}}
```

Derzeit gilt diese Kombination aus Algorithmus und Schlüssellänge noch als sicher, aber das Zertifikat hat eine Gültigkeit von über 10 Jahren und wird vom National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) nach 2030 nicht mehr empfohlen.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: P-DCOwner] Nicht-Domänenadministrator als Domänencontroller-Besitzer
In der Domäne existieren Domänenkonten, die Eigentümer eines oder mehrerer Domänencontroller sind.

Domänenkonto:
* {{Benutzername}}

Domänencontroller:
* {{Name des Domänencontrollers$}}

Als Besitzer der Domänencontroller hat dieser Benutzer volle Berechtigungen über deren Computer-Objekte und somit über die gesamte Domäne.

Dieser Benutzer ist jedoch kein Mitglied der Domänen- oder Enterprise-Administratoren-Gruppe und wird somit möglicherweise nicht ausreichend gegen Angriffe geschützt. Das Risiko einer Kompromittierung der Domäne wird dadurch vergrössert.

[Active Directory (AD)] [Pingcastle ID: S-KerberosArmoringDC & S-KerberosArmoring] Kein Kerberos Armoring Aktiviert
Kerberos Armoring ist in der Domäne weder für Domänencontroller noch für Clients aktiviert.

Ohne Kerberos Armoring fehlt eine zusätzliche Schutzschicht, die Angriffe auf die Authentifizierung verhindert.

> Hinweis: Kerberos Armoring ist nur für mindestens eine Domänenfunktionsstufe Windows Server 2012 und mindestens Windows 8 Arbeitsstationen verfügbar. Wenn Kerberos Armoring für andere Betriebssysteme (z. B. Windows 7 oder Linux) angefordert wird, funktioniert das Kerberos-Authentifizierungsprotokoll möglicherweise nicht.
