External and Anonymous Users Control Shared Desktop
It is possible for external and anonymous users to ask for the control of a shared desktop. {{Customer}} users can permit these requests
This might allow attackers to perform malicious activities such as installing malware or altering configurations. In addition, it might allow unauthorized access to sensitive data and loss of control over a presentation  or shared resources.

{{> **Remark:** The fact that anonymous users are permitted to join meetings increases the severity of this finding.}}

Add New Group Members to Group Chats
Any user can add new group members from a trusted tenant to a group chat. In addition to this, the history of the group chat (old messages) can also be shared with the new users.
This presents a potential security risk in that it may result in the disclosure of confidential messages to new group members.

Anonymous Users in Teams Meeting
It is possible for anonymous users to join a Teams Meeting. This requires the anonymous users to have the invitation URL.
This poses the risk of unauthorized access to sensitive information inside meetings, potential disruption of the meetings (e.g., through trolling or spamming) and exposure to phishing or social engineering attacks.

Receiving of Files over Teams Chats
It is possible for {{Customer}} users on Microsoft Teams to receive files from external users. 
This poses the risk of receiving malware or unwanted files from external or even anonymous users inside meetings. It should be noted that is not possible for {{Customer}} users to send files over Teams to external users.

Formatting in Messages Allowed
It is possible to use formatting in Teams messages.
This allows users to send messages that are formatted in a special way. Attackers can abuse this feature to format URLs, which can then be used to launch phishing attacks using spoofed URLs.

App Upload to Teams Apps
Users are allowed to upload apps into the {{Customer}} Teams Appstore .
These apps have to be approved by an administrator before they are available to download for all users, but the initial upload itself already poses  a security risk, as malicious or unverified apps can be introduced into the system.

Teams Accessible via Browser
Microsoft Teams can be accessed via a browser. The users of {{Customer}} are allowed to log in to the Teams web app.
This allows the employees to use Teams outside of the organization’s  network. In addition to this, it allows attackers to log in to compromised accounts.

Public Teams Available
There are {{3}} public teams available to join for any user inside {{Customer}}.
This might allow access to sensitive information in the form of potential data leakage and exposure of confidential communications or documents.

[Windows Client] "Point and Print Restrictions" nicht gehärtet
Die "Point and Print Restrictions" sind auf dem Client nicht korrekt
gesetzt. Der Client ist dadurch anfällig für die sogenannte
"PrintNightmare"-Sicherheitslücke. Die vorgefundenen
Einstellungen erlauben es einem Benutzer ohne Administratoren-
Rechte Druckertreiber zu installieren.
Ein Angreifer kann diese Fehlkonfiguration ausnutzen, um über
den lokalen Druckerwarteschlangedienst Schadsoftware über
Druckertreiber mit erhöhten Rechten (LOCAL SYSTEM)
auszuführen.
Betroffener Registry-Schlüssel:
► HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows NT\Printers\
PointAndPrint
Folgende Registry-Einträge sind nicht korrekt gesetzt:
► NoWarningNoElevationOnInstall
– Wert: 1
► UpdatePromptSettings
– Wert: 2
Betroffener Registry-Schlüssel:
► HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows NT\Printers\
PackagePointAndPrint
Folgende Registry-Einträge fehlen:
► PackagePointAndPrintServerList
– Wert: -
► PackagePointAndPrintOnly
– Wert: -
Zusätzliche Informationen zu der Sicherheitslücke sind unter
anderem in folgenden Security Advisories von Microsoft zu finden:
► KB5005010
► KB5005652

[Web] JavaScript-Code unauthentisiert verfügbar
Es handelt sich bei der Applikation um eine Single Page App, bei der die gesamte Applikationslogik in einer JavaScript-Quelldatei enthalten ist. Diese JavaScript-Datei ist unauthentisiert verfügbar.

Ein unauthentisierter Angreifer kann somit die ganze Applikationslogik analysieren und nach ungeschützten API-Endpunkten, sensiblen Informationen wie z. B. API Keys oder anderen Schwachstellen in der Applikation suchen.

Während des Tests wurde folgende JavaScript-Datei verwendet:
- {{/path/to/main.hash.js}}

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]:Permissive Password Reset Settings
Some permissions for the password reset settings are too permissive.

The following settings are affected:
- "Number of methods required to reset" is set to "1". This means that only one alternate method is necessary to reset the password.
-"Number of days before users are asked to re-confirm their authentication information" is set to "360". This setting is intended to confirm their registered information after a certain period of time.

Requiring only one method to reset passwords makes it easier for attackers to bypass security if they obtain a single piece of user information.  Additionally, waiting a full year (360 days) to re-confirm user authentication weakens its effectiveness, as contact information or security questions might become outdated over such a long period.

More information:
- https://portal.azure.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_IAM/PasswordResetMenuBlade/~/AuthenticationMethods

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Conditional Access Policies Set to Report-Only
Multiple policies are only set to report-only.

Affected policies:
- {{policies}}

This can create a false sense of security, as critical controls appear to be in place but are not actually protecting the system. Additionally, the delayed response to security incidents increases risk and potential damage before appropriate actions can be implemented.

More information:
- https://portal.azure.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_ConditionalAccess/ConditionalAccessBlade/~/Policies

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Permissive Group Settings
Some permissions for the group setting are too permissive.

The following settings are affected:
- "Owners can manage group membership requests in My Groups" is set to "Yes".
- "Users can create security groups in Azure portals, API or PowerShell" is set to "Yes".
- "Users can create Microsoft 365 groups in Azure portals, API or PowerShell" is set to "Yes".

Letting anyone create groups cuts out access controls. This exposes sensitive information and lets risky users grant themselves unauthorized access.

More information:
- https://portal.azure.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_IAM/GroupsManagementMenuBlade/~/General

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Permissive Password Protection Settings
Some permissions for the password protection setting are too permissive.

The following settings are affected:
- "Enforce custom list" is set to "No".
- "Mode" is set to "Audit".
With these settings, custom password requirements are not enforced, allowing weak passwords.  Additionally, running in audit mode only logs attempts to use weak passwords, but does not prevent them, leaving the system vulnerable.

More information:
- https://portal.azure.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_ConditionalAccess/PasswordProtectionBlade

[Azure Active Directory (AAD)][Microsoft Entra ID]: Permissive Device Settings
Some permissions for the device setting are too permissive.

The following settings are affected:
- "Users may join devices to Microsoft Entra" is set to "All".
- "Restrict users from recovering the BitLocker key(s) for their owned devices" is set to "No".

Allowing all users to join any device expands the attack surface.  If a single device gets compromised, it could be used to access the entire network. Additionally, letting users recover their own BitLocker keys removes a layer of protection. If a device is stolen with an unencrypted drive, the data could be exposed.

More information:
- https://portal.azure.com/#view/Microsoft_AAD_Devices/DevicesMenuBlade/~/DeviceSettings/menuId~/null

[Active Directory (AD)] Windows 2016 ADPREP Installation Problem
When running ADPREP under an outdated Windows Server 2016 version, there was an error that caused the ‘Enterprise Key Admins’ group to receive elevated permissions on the domain object. 

Users or computer objects belonging to the ‘Enterprise Key Admins’ group can thus compromise the domain.

[Active Directory (AD)] LAPS Missing
No use of the Local Administrator Password Solution (LAPS) was detected. It is therefore assumed that the passwords of local administrator users are not managed centrally. This often results in the same password being set on different devices. 

If a client is compromised and the password hash or administrator password is accessed, it can be used to log in locally to the clients that have the same password.

[TLS] Fehlende OCSP / CRL URIs. Keine Überprüfung des Widerrufsstatus von Zertifikaten
Aufgrund der fehlenden Implementierung von OCSP (Online Certificate Status Protocol) und CRLs (Certificate Revocation List) findet keine Überprüfung des Gültigkeitsstatus von Zertifikaten statt.

Unter diesen Umständen können Zertifikate weiterhin verwendet werden, auch wenn sie beispielsweise aufgrund einer Kompromittierung für ungültig erklärt wurden. Dies begünstigt Man-in-the-Middle-Angriffe und weitere Attacken auf die Integrität, Authentizität oder Vertraulichkeit.

[OAuth] Authorization Code in Session Storage
Der verwendete Authorization Code wird im Session Storage gespeichert.

Die Daten im lokalen Speicher des Browsers können durch JavaScript-Code gelesen und verändert werden, was ein Angreifer bei einer Cross-Site-Scripting-Attacke nutzen kann, um an das Token zu gelangen oder dieses zu ändern. Der Zugriff auf den lokalen Speicher ist jeweils für alle Applikationen aus dem "Same-Origin" möglich. Dazu gehören aber unter Umständen auch JavaScript Code, der von Drittparteien nachgeladen wird, wie z.B. Tracking-Code oder Analytic- oder Advertising-Code, womit Drittpartien Zugriff auf diese Token erhalten.

> Hinweis: Das Angriffsfenster ist sehr klein, da zusätzlich zum Authorization Code auch ein Client Secret notwendig ist, um dieses Verhalten auszunutzen. Zudem ist der Code nur einmalig gültig.

[OAuth] Unterstützung von unsicheren Grant Typen
Die OpenID-Connect-Konfiguration von Keycloak unterstützt verschiedene "Grant Types'' die als nicht sicher gelten. 

Betroffene URL:
```
/realms/egov//.well-known/openid-configuration
```

```
{
    "grant_types_supported": [
        "authorization_code",
        "implicit",
        "refresh_token",
        "password",
        "client_credentials",
        "urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:device_code",
        "urn:openid:params:grant-type:ciba"
    ]
}
```

Unter Umständen ist es einem Angreifer möglich einen 
access Token abzufangen, sofern ein unsicherer Grant Type verwendet wird. Dieser könnte dann verwendet werden, um unautorisierten Zugriff auf die geschützten Ressourcen zu erlangen.
